bounden lord b c fideli svo amico b c gallicae academiae nonlatin alphabet siquis natiuo solo collocatus honestis quibusuis circumflues voluptatibus nec vlla necessitate eo impulsus se tame amicorum hortatu turbulentissimas mari tempestates conijceret vt pretiosam margaritam suis multu desideratam coparareticerte laudanda foret eius tantis laboribus subeundis alacritas postqua secundo vento vsus sit summa cu laetitia excipiendus illius reditus peregre vt mihi visum est profectus e aliquantisper charissime amice licet ea fuit vitae tuae coditio vt bonis literis te oblectans ijs tanqua tua patria consistere potuisses voluisti tame amicoru rogatu fluctibus te obijcere per aliquos scopulos velut gallicam regione nauigare vt hanc splendidissima gemmam academiam nempe florentissima nobis etiam amicis tuis communicare posse appulisti tandem ad portu syrtes omnes praeteruectus e exoptata margarita tuo opere assequuti sumus possumus ergo quin tuam istis laboribus suscipiendis voluntate libenter agnoscamus et ijsde exantlandis foelicitate libere praedicemus quamuis vero mul orum oculis vilescere coepit philosophia cuius abditos sauros luce protulisti eiusmodi tamen sunt quorum autoritas propter hominum leuitatem nullius est momenti quos vere perstringit illud sermone tritum prouerbiu scientia non habet inimicum nisi ignorantem quis maronem bathyllo atrocior quis vlyssem thersite acerbior quis dialecticis arg tijs epicuro infestior et quales quaeso sunt qui canino latratu impetunt philosophia nisiqui huius reginae aedes ne limine salutarunt siergo apud istos forsita sordescant tuae vigiliae ne demittas tamen animu ne que enim tam acre est eorum iudicium vt iam pertimescas nec lingua adeo virulenta vt vel minimam labeculam tuo nomini aspergere possit ne solis quidem lumen caeco iucundum est saluberrima pharmaca ab imperitis conculcantur pretiosissimae gemma gallo aesopico spernuntur ip philosophia vitae lucerna ment medicina gemma lucidissima caecis stolidis brutis contemnitur si aut cum neoptolemo apud ennium philosophandum saltem putassent licet paucis aut cum diuo paulo nonlatin alphabet duntaxat nonlatin alphabet reiecissent no minime repugnantes habuissent quum vero vna cum apollonio philosophiam ludibrio habeant eam que ab omni vetustate constitutam cum arcesila penitus labefactent nullo modo audiendi aut ferendi sunt sicut dicaearchus aristoxenus quia difficilis erat animi quid aut qualis esset intelligentia nullum omnino animum esse dixerunt ita isti quorum obtusa acies philosophiae insignes fructus aspicere nequit nullum esse omnino philosophiae vsum clamitant verum enimuero hab eat philosophia suam laudem sit vitae dux morum magistra virtutis columna ei tanquam reginae solium suum tribuatur tuae tamen laudes nullae erunt nullae e manebit laurea nullum hic est tuum inuentum nullum tui acuminis specimen nisi velis tanquam ignauus mile de spolijs aliorum sudore partis gloriari latronum aliorum bona alijs impressis notis tanquam tua venditare siccine vero quid ita tandem noui ego mi amice animi tui indolem nullam que vt ingenue dicam quod long docuit experientia nonlatin alphabet te contemplari potui quamuis nulla benefacta lucem reformident ea tame semper laudabiliora duxisti quae sine venditatione populo teste facta sunt nullum que theatrum virtuti conscientia maius indicasti cuius rei vel hoc vnicum satis est argumenti quod non sicut illi philosophi de contemnenda gloria scribentes sua nomina libris apposuerunt voluisti hoc tuum opus tuum fronte nomen gerere sed publicum potius commodum quam priuatam gloriam respiciens incerto maluisti librum prodire authore quam no certa carere vtilitate gloria autem indiuidua virtutis come vide vt te quamuis fugientem sequatur neque enim nihili est tua industria aestimanda quamuis alterius vestigijs institisti nec parui ducendae sunt tuae vigiliae licet alterius opere prius elucubrata fuit ista academia aurum argentum alunt ipsa terrae viscera illis tamen nonnihildebemus quorum sudore ista metalla effodiuntur omne fere genus mercaturae aliquibus locis sua sponte nascitur suo tamen honore minime spoliandi sunt mercatores quorum cum periculo vitae que crebra iactura tanta nobis bona comportata sunt sit itaque primaudayi aurea ista academia illius sit pretiosissima haec supellex tibi tamen aliquid interea laudis relinquatur cuius industria nisi sese opportune interposuisset anglis nostris nihil inde emolumenti redundasset neque est quod quispiam agre ferat siphilosophia graeca ac romana veste vt plurimum induta iam incipiat britannico quoque vestitu incedere bonum enim vt pulchre philosophus quo communius eo melius philosophiaipsa solo haud dissimilis omnes terrarum orbes radio suos disseminare cupit argiuorumres gestae celebres factae sunt primoab homero neque tamen lusit suam operam virgilius cum easdem suo carmine celebrauit philosophia diu graeciae regionibus septis inclusa mansit nunquam tamen consenescet ciceronis laus qui eam ipsam latinis literis illustrauit et grata vti spero memoria tuos labores prosequentur omnes quibus factu est vt academia ista gallicis antea circumscripta terminis anglis iamtandem innotescat macte igitur virtute charissime amice maiores tibi addant spiritus istae primitiae ad maiora si iusta se offerat occasio suscipienda spero etenim aliquando euenturum vt sicut philosophico certamine vires tuae se exeruerint ita etiam theologico puluere pari saltem foelicitate exspatientur interim bene vale octobr tui studiosissimus g christian king france polonia henrie third name sir credit miserable contentation man find therein seeing good commonly slippeth away soone receiued alwaies worketh vnsatiable desire thereof felicitie shall expect looke fruition thing waxeth old perisheth men poore estate man life fairest race commeth nothing twinkling eie bodily shewe brightnes turneth suddenly putrefaction doth try would full life sharpe griefes pricking misery assaulted continuall trouble many percing care doth abound griping griefes doe pursue briefly wise grecian said hauing bare name life effect truth continuall paine truly thing hath beeing deede changeth without ceasing nature man doth neuer continueth estate least moment would gladly aske thee readest doest meane reade day hower thou hast passed passest ouer since thou hadst iudgement knowledge wherein thy body hath pleasant peaceable quiet life effect thing woorthy beseeming certaine hope shal one day grace god framed new eternal happy contented life let v therefore account world rich thereof thing belonging straunger nothing appertaining men beyng regenerated spirite grace haue profited well schoole wisedome let v seeke friendshippe vpon earth let v couete rich glory honour pleasure none fooles doe extoll desire wonder wee worlde straungers onely therein therefore let v set worldly thing behinde v account vnwoorthie care immortall soules meane perish worlde ioyning selues thereunto let v forsake contentation minde thing present academie doth onely set eye also doth saue keepe v beyng already entered hauen safetie agaynst tempestes wee selues spare labour reape profite learned wise instruction giuen vnto v preceptes doctrine example lyues auncient vertuous famous men first wee shall learne hereby know selues ende beyng secondly wee shall bee instructed good maners taught may liue well happily euery estate condition lyfe whatsoeuer yea shall finde basest lowest estate ignorant common sort people oftentimes called miserable much ioy happinesse monarch partaker fruition greatnesse yea much bee wicked bicause vice estate maketh possessour thereof wretched contrarywise vertue maketh euery condition life happy moreouer wee shall see academie euery one louyng fearing god may obtaine inestimable good vertue thereby remayne conquerour ouer perturbation soule breede miserie remembring poynt alwayes farre foorth fraile nature man ayded author goodnesse attayne perfection wee shall learne ought gouerne selues wisely duetifully humane action affaire charge place whatsoeuer either publique priuate whereunto shall called may note cause subuersion ruine many empire estate student first discourse vnto last intent thou maiest vnderstand large entrance assembly teach themselues next euery one according abilitie institution good maners rule good lining ordinarie common almost resembleth another great varietie two found resembling point one another read euen sundry nation haue taken indifferently one stranger matter maruellous men hauing toong wherewith speake sing ancient philosopher thales milesius one sage graecia florished athens time achab king iuda first definition soulethat defined soule affirming nature alwaies moouing selfe pythagoras light time first tooke vnto himselfe name philosopher pythagoras first called philosopherbicause addicted contemplation diuinity secret nature caused themselues called name mages wisemen would haue spoken himselfe saying diuine lofty title wise proper god onely farre passed humane ability say excellent man pythagoras affirmed soule number moouing selfe plato saith spiritual substance moouing selfe harmonicall number aristotle saith soule continuall act moouing naturall instrumentall bodie may haue life else according others light substance perpetuall motion diui e likewise diuersely make many part therof soule diuision soule pythagoras said compounded vnderstanding knowledge opinion sence thing knowledge art proceed man called reasonable apt discourse reason plato saith plato maketh sixe part soulethere three vertues soule belonging knowledge vnderstanding cause called cognitiue knowing vertues namely reason vnderstanding phantasie vnto three others answerable appertaining appetite namely whose office desire vnderstanding reason propound vnto choler anger followeth reason phantasie offer vnto concupiscence apprehendeth whatsoeuer phantasie andaristotle diuideth two part sence obiect vnto aristotle maketh another distinction soule saying one part voide reason selfe yet may guided reason part selfe partaker reason another place philosopher saith three thinges whence humane action proceed namely sence vnderstanding appetite many others ancient late writer make foure part soule vnderstandingfoure part soule reason anger desire vnderstanding lifteth soule vp heauen contemplation diuine intellectual thing reason guideth soule prudence function anger ruled moderated vertue magnanimitic desire gouerned temperance harmonicall iustice framed giueth euerie part soule belongeth vnto sensible common true opinion wisest amongst philosopher hadthe best diuision soule soule diuideth two part onely vnder rest comprised one spiritual intelligible discourse reason brutish sensuall selfe wandring disordred motion contrarie reason euill desire haue dwelling amongst philosophical discourse soule written great personage error verie great attribute strength power reason say resident soule lampe guide vnderstanding queene moderate alone man may wel iustly gouerne himselfe although know reason man selfe wholy depraued corrupted yet may say wel enough soule spirit life cannot diuided immortall bicause whatsoeuer diuided dissolueth parteth sunder whatsoeuer dissolued perisheth neuertheles may said compounded made subiect coniunction thereof withthe soule cannot diuided made subiect two part body two principall part vnderstanding vnderstanding serueth conceaue comprehend thing propounded vnto v discerne iudge ought either approoue allow refuse reiect executeth bringeth effect whatsoeuer vnderstanding iudgeth good contrariwise flieth reprooueth condemneth herein agree philosopher vnderstanding vnder comprehend sence gouernour captaine soule dependeth withall say one corrupted altered nature vnderstanding obscured dimmed cloud darknes reason first man sinne descended vponboth part soule corrupted posteritie hereditarie naturall filthines sort corrupted disobedience weakened made feeble goodnes none guide comming aboue teach vnderstanding direct leade meane regeneration spirite god cannot euill drawing soule vtter ruine perdition causing consent law contentation occasion proceeding see perceiue profite amende studie appeare vnto v consideration may know whether profit philosophieof present work action compared former diminishing qualifiying afterwarde right perfect way hereunto enter deepely selues take perfect sound knowledge naturall hurtfull vehement inclination comparing one another next good expert phisition dealeth dangerous disease beginneth good way ouercome great faultswith gentle preparatiues first correct lesser fault may easier ouercome greatest certaine exercise custome keeping selues thing sort excusable yea permitted lawfull farre easie v afterward amend abstaine vnlawfull thing haue thus reformed selues shall wholy forsake small imperfection easie v make reckoning little offence shall auoid altogither doubled vpon bicause better seene noted whereby become odious contemptible euery one besides reward lieth gate great measure long giuen shall good lesson great menbe required pray greater cause shame also vseth minister instrument corrupt spoile others propertie wickedyou shall neuer see wicked man laboureth make others like himselfe cannot yet thinke seeke persuade others rather worse himselfe disquietnes euen dreames life time destitute tranquillitie rest spirit wherein humane felicitie consisteth therefore one hebrew interpreter well truly answered king ptolemie asked might rest dreamed torment lesse wise man neuer thinketh knowing ought reuerence himselfe others rather greeuous within v feare worldly shame punishment apprehension iust iudgement god nothing hid pursueth wicked hard heeles part knoweth take vengeance iniquitie due time defer punishment serueth god deferreth vengeance vpon wickedaggrauate condemnation much vpon head make punishment horrible whereof ought stand greater feare bodily paine bicause dolor thereof abideth euer would go repeate heer seuerally al vice wherewith men may infected wherein see commonly wallow find number great yea infinite democritus said let v onely lay open within v shal find heap conserue many diuers different euils haue originall beginning thence shadowes follow body passion vice follow soules heerafter may discourse particularly greater part proper peculiar effect iust punishment commonly followed meane time may learne custome great force say ouercommeth nature chiefly seene vice dissolutenes gulfe wherein man may easily cast himselfe custome sinning dangerousheadlong difficult matter yea vnpossible withdraw himselfe againe wise romane said horrible execrable offence vse custome made small fault commonly practised propertie vice headstrong contentious seeking defend selfe reason although altogither vaine friuolous yet great waight regard weake flesh man easily suffereth selfe bound vnder yoke sinne therefore take good heed suffer selues surprised dangerous enimie giue accesse entrance v mean dwell v otherwise know perfect righteousnes god onely rather let v exercise fortifie selues viceall thing contrarie vice accustoming selues sort maister common small imperfection abundant iustest men take effect howsoeuer themselues may seeme excusable meanes shall labor euermore make choise best indifferet thing stand v stead sure rampire tyrannicall raigne enimie vertue read pythagoras accustomed himselfe abstain crueltie iniustice euen towards brute beast humanitie pythagoras euen towards brute beastsrequesting fowler taken bird let flie againe came amongst fisherman bought draught caused fish cast againe sea moreouer forbad disciple kill tame beast time example let v abstaine thing may procure vice neuer suffer speech passe v good wanting deale maner another time better oh slipperie way easily doth vice glide away like streame vnder excellent comparison teaching v suffer vnlawfull thingsuch pretence wedge maketh smal cleft beginning yet afterward rift greater sundereth al peeces sufferance vnlawful thing small soeuer leadeth men little little vnmeasurable licentiousnes moreouer assure himselfe tomorrow yea quarter hower oracle apollo answered cyrrha would liue peace among themselues make continuall war neighbor stranger may passe course short day peace rest tranquillitie spirit fall cruell paw aduersarie goodnes must daily fight must neuer harken herald vicehim neuer giue eare herald ambassador peace pleasure neglect dutie bait presenteth v deceiue beguile v withal certaine vice putteth vice deceiueth menon visard goeth disguised couered goodly shewes belong onely vertue chalengeth falsely vnto selfe good indeed truth man ought desire thus clothed helpe corruptible pleasure lightly passe away yoketh base minded men whose care onely set vpon desire earthly thing setteth eies felicitie impudently imputing vertue euils selfe haue sufficiently profited philosophy knowledge good thing truly faire beautiful neuer harken hurtfull allurement rather prudence serpentas serpent doth stoppeth hir eares hir taile end may heare charmes sorcery inchanter neglect good admonition giue place amongst v neuer little bait vice may easily end thornes thistle growing neere good seed oftentimes choke darken good instinct nature shall v diogenes cynike walking one day diogenes asked almes imagesstreet athens wherein many image ancient men best deserued commonwelth asked almes one another whereat maruelling demanding cause learne quoth take deniall patiently euen far command selues shun vaine vnprofitable busines wherin age delighteth serue allurement bait nicenes pleasure let v ashamed follow rather let v say learne contemne contemptible make choice according ancient precept pythagoras best kind life end custome may little little make easie pleasant vnto v conclude therefore present matter say vice inseparably accompanied thousand misery vnspeakeable exceeding mischief draw man vtter ruine eternall perdition may truly called onely euill soule selfe able sufficient make vnhappy receineth ghest hurtfull thing ought hate flie meanes vertue contrarie vnto labouring meanes haue soules pure cleane wicked deed wils counsel maners vndefiled troubled infected euill perturbation wherewith vice alwaies aboundeth rich science honest thing according dutie wherunto called nature onely selues also benefit profit many therefore thee achitob shall vnderstand large dutie honestie achitob treatise philosophie saith cicero necessarie office dutie forasmuch part man life whether publike priuate affaire action soeuer either ought may destitute therof therein consisteth honestie life neglected infamie albeit part ancient philosopher comprehended duty honestie vnder vertue affirming one thing yet following opinion great orator philosopher hath handled morall philosophie good order may distinguish sort saying dutie end whereunto vertue tendeth namely action obserue honestie comlines distinction see neuertheles coniunction three thing vertue dutie honestie one end perfection thereof consisting three togither dutie u ie isi bindeth soule cheerfully willingly without force constraint giue euery one belongeth vnto honor honor reuerence reuerence tribute tribute diuision dutieand succor succor belongeth dutie diuided two generall kind one appertaineth perfect souereigne good concerneth preseruation safetie common societie men consisteth morall precept according behauior al sort life may squared dutie owe god law mother vertuesthis obedience grounded vpon rule perfect righteousnes giuen vnto v law god mother preseruer vertues yea dutie towards neighbour isbeginning roote al goodnes part dutie respecteth neighbor whereof chiefly intreat academie nothing charity loue like selues greatly recommended vnto v scripture requisit vnto saluation dutie whereby bound thing publike lawes equitie profit alwaies constant perfect exercise vse vertue honest seemely thing owne sake necessitie constraint onely borne saith cicero selues countrie parent friend ought reape commoditie birth whatsoeuer vpon earth created men themselues man created manthat one might aide helpe another follow nature must imploy good trauell industrie whatsoeuer else power behalfe common commoditie preseruation humane societie yea man liueth happily little may liueth himselfe side man liueth disorderedly liueth himselfe thinketh nothing owne profit dutie requireth safetie parent friend countrie offer selues peril respecting owne profit commoditie neither ought esteeme thing iust profit separated honestieprofitable except honestie linked togither philosopher say separated whitenes cold snow heate light fire man perswaded rule honestie profit one neuer without fraud wickednes thinking thus himselfe indeed honest profitable feare breake rent sunder equitie ordained appointed either diuine humane lawes diuision fountaine vice falshood mischiefe good man saith plato may slander steale lie owne commoditie thing world great value treasure pretious ought cause v loose name vertuous iust ought rather turne profit towards honestie sort howsoeuer word seeme differ one another yet make one thing moreouer diuine philosopher saith true beautie soule honestie nothing else brightnes perfect chiefe good appeereth thing may knowen eies eares mind whereby caused returne towards idea paterne goodnes wherby excellent man meaneth thing giue v vnderstand whatsoeuer goodnes honestie v commeth god fountaine thereof vnto vertue returneth leading soule liue eternally besides commeth beginning proceeding good work yea maketh v go forward according true dutie consisteth two thing requisite euerie good workethese two point first intention end action rightly framed secondly like meanes attaine end found two thing may agree disagree one another see sometimes end well propounded yet men erre meanes attaine vnto contrariwise falleth oftentimes meanes good end propounded bad liuely euerflowing fountaine cause al good whence looke perfect knowledge dutie end meanes whereby execute glorie god good profit like generall vertue fountaine honestie fower riuers issue fountaine dutiedutie fower riuers issue spring called morall vertues namely prudence guide rest knoweth profitable selfe others commonwealth temperance mistres modestie chastitie sobrietie vigilancie order mediocritie thing fortitude maketh man constant patient couragious hardie readie enterprise high great profitable holie thing iustice bond preseruation humane societie giuing euery one belongeth vnto keeping faith thing promised succoring gladly afflicted helping euery one according abilitie serueth vertues true certain good soule whereby action directed according dutie shall speake particularly thereof heerafter meane let v enter example ancient see exactly inuiolably obserued point dutie choosing rather sacrifice liues infringe breake much contemning weaker occasion wherwith lewd baseminded people suffer themselues easily corrupted first touching first point dutie naturally example zeale ancient seruice godimprinted soules greatest infidel acknowledge diuinitie zeale although inconsiderate rash ancient heathen pagan precisely obserue paganisme euen sacrificing cheerfull offering vp owne child god read carthaginian say child yea would receiue image temple refused petronius said vnto belike would fight caesar weighing wealth owne weakenes vnabilitie fight quoth rather die turne lawes god foorthwith casting themselues ground seruice thought great happines lose liues truly besides sweet affection nature hath imprinted hart towards countrie conformitie humor commonly found body heauenly aire wher haue first breathing forceable meanes procuring publike place authoritie many senator opinion pompey chosen sole onely consul cato also mind saying men ought choose lesse euill meete redresse greater mischief better vice auoided action either publike priuate orderly according dutie executed weake diseased sight cannot behold light sunne vnskilfull soule cannot know truth vnskilfulnes causeth man fall seueritie pernitious effect ignorancethinks exercise iustice would liberall becommeth prodigall thinketh auoid superfluitie falleth couetousnes haue apprehension diuine nature consumeth soule confused feare superstition mind cannot conceiue happy blessed nature forthwith iudgeth none thus guided ignorance desire inclination tend wretchednes miserie moreouer plato saith ignorance taketh away sight mind tainted therewith blindnes taketh away sight corporall eies lacke sight testifieth ignorant mind vile wretched expedient liue liue ignorance giue credit cicero onely liueth indeed possesseth soule setling himselfe good matter seeketh renowme notable fact good art good saith socrates leaue altogither vse thing wherof haue skill vse well know vse eies eares whole bodie profitable neither see heare helpe themselues way bodie like maner better knoweth use soule haue none liue must need liue borne happier estate slaue free man speech wise philosopher expoundeth selfe sufficiently tending end giue v vnderstand better yea neuer haue borne ignorance follow vice dangerous man may freely without feare greater himselfe droonkennes engendreth rage madnes saith aristotle ignorance ioined power begetteth insolencie furie one plato saith place ignorant man authoritie lay great burden vpon shoulder man halfe dead weakenes thing make iudge ignorant man onely say like image blocke wood maner nothing differing brute beast caused ancient vse saying ignorant men euillthat euery ignorant man euill terence going yet saith earth beareth nothing worse ignorant man truth mischief see come ignorance man meane base effect ignorance rich pooreestate maketh good nothing fearfull superstitious vnprofitable needie vnciuill slothfull vnfit euery good thing mightie rich besides may fall said misery imperfection much sooner become arrogant cruell rash talkatiue couetous vnconstant giuen voluptuousnes vniust word meanes shall haue exercise vice richer grow ignorance able gouerne himselfe must need vnwoorthie intermeddle either politicall oeconomicall gouernment ignorant man possesse great benefit felicitie neuer know much hath lost againe moreouer mischiefe followeth neuer make profit good counsell bicause presumption owne opinion alwaies thinketh better yea supposeth nothing well done except put helping hand menander saith nothing rash ignorance ignorant man lift vp vnto excellencie dignitie rich vnsufferable one knoweth vse puffed vp pride aboue measure content estate driuen ambition presumeth oftentimes vndertake thing reason equitie contrariwise fortune change abaseth himselfe measure shewing nothing abiection mind inconstancy impatiencie great trouble disquietnes spirit oftentimes wholie besides himselfe small fruit ignorance namely make man importunate cause common effect ignoranceto stay another hath great affaire saying hath many thing communicate vnto truth small pleasure desire one hath lost suite bestow dinner vpon promising tell way may recouer againe speake ill woman inuited wedding companie request walke hath alreadie gone great way seeth thing sold bring chapman seller would haue giuen great deale repeate one thing oftentimes shew himselfe readie man would haue yet dare well denie woonder thing speake word vnskilfull man alwaies place affaire vnciuill impertinent example foresaid effect familiar amongst v first concerning small meane estate condition many million men haue age past liue yet among v whose life ignorant euery good cause reason much vnlike spring errorsmany thing worse brute beast originall many error foolish opinion impiety hath passage midst soules bicause true knowledge end liue thence commeth best aduised among exercise base handicraft desirous learne lead seruile contemptible life bringing body soules subiection lust wicked desire greater sort others remaine idle vnprofitable seeking maintaine liues vnlawfull meanes blockish ignorance depriue themselues present eternall felicitie albeit poore men haue great meanes execure wicked desire may sort seeme tollerable excuseable man iudgement bicause ignorance doth greatly hurt themselues yet falleth far worse haue wealth authoritie command others knowing vse good well vertuous deed abuse vice dissolutenes pleasure whereby part cast themselues headlong infidelitie atheisme bicause neuer true vnderstanding perfect diuinitie yet considered confusion moouing star season yeere reuolutions course sunne earth causeth day night nourishing preseruation sort liuing creature generation yeerly fruit thousand good consideration beleeued returne matter certaine higher ignorant men aduanced much without question fault greater meaner estate bicause hurtfull many yea oftentimes hath come passe one onely fault man hath losse destruction infinite number nicias feared eclipse moonemen nicias general captain athenian feare conceiued darkness eclipse moone knowing cause thereof staied long vntill enimies inclosed round whereupon taken aliue put death besides losse fortie thousand athenian caligula domitianthat taken slaine doubteth ignorance draue caligula domitian pride crueltie whilst sought worshipped stead true god cause death haue concorde agreement one another moreouer found friendship whatsoeuer men thinke woorthie desired honestie glorie tranquillitie minde pleasure consequently happie life cannot bee amongst friendship friendship bicause loue desire thing loued beginning friendship friendship inueterate ancient loue wherein pleasure desire loue saith cicero nothing else desirous profit pleasure another without hope recompence otherwise friendship would bee meere merchandise whereas ought free charitie socrates also said end friendship two soules one made affection none loue himselfe better friend meane kept thing except conuersing friend regard ought resolued vpon either wholie forsaken wholie trusted shall hide friend saith homer letteth may thinke selfe alone whereby appeereth vnto v friend second selfe whosoeuer would take vpon thing requisite friendshipthis title regard another must transforme himselfe nature purposeth loue stedfast setled mind continue euer heereupon one ancient speaking loueth perfectly saith liueth another man bodie friend therefore ought necessitie haue coniunction conformitie maners desire passion speech study pleasure inclination intermission mind professe perfect friendship whereby may easily ghesse entertaineth many friend depriueth himselfe name true stedfast friend bicause altogither vnpossible man fashion himselfe pattern apply himselfe nature diuers euery one especially considering shall hardly find himselfe like affected thing one alone haue found disposition conformitie offereth himselfe bee friend wee must enter knowledge sounding depth hart wee may certaine sure good disposition see outwardly resemblance maners condition another sufficient prooue deede without dissimulation vnlesse bee grounded vpon good vertuous nature simple truly great rich nothing ought desire preserue keepe first mutuall opinion ought euerie friend vertue companion serueth much matter cicero saith opinion vertue fountaine friendship proper vertue win men hart draw vnto selfe preserue friendship next coniunction maners wils keepeth backe riot contention mind one shall sooner declared presently putteth helping hand bring passe thirdly obserue first thing must hold generall rule haue alreadie touched true perfect friendship ought friendship must freefree charitie whence hath hir beginning meane ought exercise selfe hire recompence onely loue beloued v one proper friend sauoreth hireling true friend day like crowes fly towards place thing feed vpon euen commonly visit men house except profit neither reuerence friend longer see prosperitie may reape commoditie must shun parasite saluting table friend moreouer must reioice delight companie conuersation friend wherein sweetest pleasant fruit friendship consisteth want benefit friend must often communicate togither letter thereby shew liue remembrance one another letter true friend spirit refreshed eies delighted friendship confirmed mind contented besides must haue vertues spirit prosperitie yea acquaintance common togither nothing secret hidden lastly must yeeld friend duty seruices sincere friendship honest profitable thing according right iustice bound limit holie loue desiring like towards v aboue thing affliction aduersitie iniurie offered ought common v wherein assist helpe succor sweet consolation souereigne fit remedie applied vnto especially good doctrine aduersitie doubt adde much grace pleasure prosperitie may effect dutie whatsoeuer owe friend many way owe dutie friendsuccouring fower thing namely person good comfort counsell may also comprehend vnder two duty releeuing necessitie friend comforting tribulation bicause perfection soeuer friend likewise selues cannot alwaies imperfection mingled therewith men doings neuer without euill must presume able build perfect friendship shall void free vice therefore must beare imperfection friendwe must gently support beare want discommodities friend oftentimes frame selues many passion directly contrarie vertue proceed imbecillitie frailtie nature common v neuertheles imperfection must time conuenient purpose vse free gentle admonition necessarie friendship worthie consideration opinion shall well make seuerall discourse thereof come passe displeasure iar happen betweene v time wherin ought studie labour may profitable honorable thing friend harken slanderous toongs watch small light occasion powre poison discord thereby rent breake sunder good sure friendship parasite scrapgatherers freecost feast seeke nothing gain disagreement others must neuer giue eare driue far v thinke come neer v end may better affected disposed heerunto must often call remembrance benefit happines commeth men linked togither true vnfained friendship namely affaire cannot present selues fidelitie friend supplieth place whence draw conclusion violateth friendship setteth himselfe common succour aide men much lieth ouerthroweth humane societie cannot thing selues therefore friendship ioined togither mutuall duty one may profit another considering aboue named thing necessarie also hard difficult obserued kept true friendship man may easily iudge excellent sympathie fellow feeling two friend rare easily found forcible reason followeth altogither impossible plurality friendsmany friend linked togither whosoeuer goeth matter neuer attaine certaine durable friendship must needes follow beginneth new friendship cannot diminish waxe faint affection regard former friendship wherein maner setled yea obserue dutifull point stedfast friend well mutuall conuersation communication thing helping friend affaire haue many friend looke vnto may stand neede one time certaine seruing one would wanting peraduenture whilst doubteth helpe first yet matter take enimie enimie friend certainly wise man chilon fitly signified much one boasted neuer fo hast thou neuer friend quoth chilon seeing hath neuer fo hath neuer friendimpossible reason wickednes men two person liue world without enimies whereupon plutarke saith thou seekest swarme friend thou considerest thou fallest wasp neast enimies heereof history set v example true excellent friendship make best excellent friendship betweene one couplemention onely two person ionathan dauid whose friendship could hindered wrath father one although knew friend raigne ouer notwithstanding inheritance succeed next kingdome read one achilles patroclus one falsified oth would neuer fight end might reuenge death one orestes pylades calling themselues name orestes condemned die thereby saue life companion neither mo one ephenus eueritus one desite diuert quench heate vicious passion curiositie familiar amongst v vnseemlie prudent vertuous must cure curiositieman must sometimes abstaine inquiring lawfull thing though otherwise necessarie exercise practise iustice expedient sometime leaue vntaken man may lawfully take thereby accustome himselfe abstaine easily taking thing vniustly likewise good man sometime abstaine owne wife may attaine vertue temperancie neuer mooued desire another man wife like maner stead shewing selues number diligent curious inquirer vnprofitable newes signifie rather commeth tell v newes please v better good profitable matter speake thereby giue testimonie staied setled nature despising curiositie example curiositiethis noted alexander great seeing messenger running apace towards smiling countenance said vnto shewing himselfe bee mooued desirous vnderstand would speake good newes canst thou bring friend vnles thou didst come tel homer risen truly great reason thinke excellencie could added valiant act deed except haue consecrated immortalitie lightnes beleefethe writing learned notable wit example phocion deserueth well heere alledged curious folk commonly light beliefe soone athenian receiued newes alexander death purposed presently alter estate shake yoke macedonian alliance phocion contrarie opinion said vnto newes true day true also morow therfore lord athenian make haste deliberate leisurely looke safely ye haue certaine vse sort shew selues staied thing thing smal importance wherein naturall inclination would prouoke v curious namely breake good communication fault whereinto curious men commonly fallbegun vpon receit letter forsake companie run meet messenger onely know newes bringeth thousand like sudden motion proceeding lightnes curiositie say auoiding thing prepare way restraining al curiositie greater matter otherwise may procure blame example open another body letter intrude selues secret counsel neighbor seeke fault imperfection inquire busily may greeue familiar friend aske like neither grounded vpon good cause reason least peraduenture answer wise man turne shame framed according desire thus dealt demaratus curious importunate wittie answer made curious questionsfellow oftentimes asked honestest man sparta resembleth thee lest quoth vnto answer also egyptian vnfitly made one asked caried folded wrapped vp quoth bicause thou shouldst know hath hitherto discoursed appeereth sufficiently al kind curiositie hurtful hateful greatly blamed euerie one bounded limited reason true prudence guideth stirreth v vp seeke good honest profitable thing either heauen earth aire sea according gift capacitie vnderstanding iudgement may necessarie v know may helpe v liue well happily whatsoeuer ought account vnprofitable superfluous let v learne academicall kind knowledge teach v know selues dutie whereby shall led happy end seeke desire let v admire merchandise outward shewes wherewith stranger feed eies curious folk let v wonder vertue onely saying comicall poet speaketh couered bedstead gold siluer great follie make sleepe deere god hath freely giuen vnto v seeke stranger great expences may haue owne hauen better co modiously one haue farre greater power ouer passion came without v fell first creation let v therefore conclude present discourse vertue temperance verie necessarie profitable happie life hath propertie belonging vnto skilfull chasing mediocritie pleasure greefes keeping honest vertuous shunning vice especially carnall pleasure although serue also moderate action life prudent man auoideth dishonest thing publike place temperate man goeth farther eschewing solitarie obscure corner iustice suffereth violence vsed wrong offered temperance permitteth none offend therefore verie well called philosopher mother dutie honestie intemperance stupiditie blockishnes chap achitob instructed vertue temperance well hir fellow vertues consisteth mediocritie consider hir extremity vice excesse defect intemperance cleane contrarie vnto cicero saith inflameth prouoketh troubleth tranquillitie spirit concerning defect find proper name giuen vnto philosopher leaue handling matter vnto companion aser intemperance saith plato called ancient bicause peruerse cruell great variable beast lust exerciseth therein power ought predominant passion intemperanceas also disordered ioy doth like whereupon commeth intemperate men enioying pleasure sens imagine falsely true felicitie accompanieth therein truly whosoeuer obeieth bodilie pleasure serueth cruell tyrant amana nature said architas hath giuen plague pernitious hurtful pleasure body wheras god hath bestowed vpon man nothing excellent soule reason none great enimie heauenlie gift voluptuousnes bicause luxuriousnes concupiscence raigne temperance haue place yea vertues banished kingdome let v heare aram discourse vice heere propounded vnto v aram sinnes punishment sinnes red plato long since many sin ought rather called punishment sin going sinnes according course sequele speech memorie good thinke meaning men suffering themselues ouertaken vice beginning sport neuer take heed vnto themselues vntill wholie abandoned giuen ouer paule saith vile affection rom pleasure hart vncleannes turbulent passion ignominie reproch insomuch haue opened gate concupiscence desire flesh whooremongers couetous person reuengers owne wrong belly god glutton lesse imperfection notwithstanding foule beastly become sodomite churchrobbers parricide epicure atheist full execrable villanies comprehended intemperance isvnder word intemperance intemperance well defined philosopher ouerflowing voluptuousnes forcing compelling reason sort consideration losse hinderance able stay keepe backe long custome infected vice betaking himselfe set purpose man would say willingly desperately execution desire lust placeth sole soueraigne good therein seeking contentation thing bringeth sens delight pleasure cause aristotle distinguisheth betweene intemperance incontinencie difference betweene incontinent intemperate manalbeit many take indifferently one saying incontinent man chooseth neither consulteth offendeth one knoweth full well euill committeth euill resolued himselfe follow ouercome perturbation yeeldeth thereunto whereas intemperate man committeth euill election setled purpose follow accounting good thing desired commeth long custom habit vice cause neuer repenteth fact taketh pleasure therein whereas contrarie side repentance incontinent man followeth hard heeles sinne transgression maner proceedeth intemperance vntill men wholie addicted giuen ouer vice cause sensuall vnreasonable part soule contendeth reason starke dead suffereth selfe caried vgly vnnaturall vice fleshly desire bicause diuine part soule weakened sort hath strength feeling hir essence enimie vice thus accustoming hir selfe follow nothing bodie forsaketh god altogither seeing himselfe forsaken leaueth hir hir concupiscence whence ingendred exceeding luxuriousnes euen nature mortall venemous bloodie enuie furious barbarous crueltie insatiable couetousnes bloudthirstie ambition incurable disease soule wel knowen amongst v whereof sequele discourse affoord ample knowledge vnto thus see intemperance cicero saith mother perturbation soule causeth man socrates said differ nothing beast bicause neuer thinketh vpon best onely seeketh satisfie content vnbridled desire pleasure lust hauing vse reason beast haue intemperance saith eusebius corrupteth soule destroieth bodie bicause constraineth man loue pleasure desire satisfie knoweth well dishonest vile wind torment fit similitudetosse ship haue seazed vpon heere suffer guided hir maister intemperance moouing compelling soule disobey reason suffereth hir enioy tranquillitie rest assured hauen harbour wind intemperance saith aristotle vice proceedeth coueting part man whereby desire enioy vnlawfull pleasure hir propertie choose fruition hurtfull vile pleasure supposing none liue happily passe away life themthe companion intemperance vice vnseparably accompanied troubling order impudencie vnseemlines luxuriousnes sloth negligence dissolutenes word intemperance remooueth troubleth tranquillitie mind leadeth men kind wickednes end one vice beginning another socrates called punishment sinne doth cleanse kill malefactor kind dissolutenes wherein intemperate man plungeth himselfe wickednes crueltie executeth satisfying vncleane desire vnsatiable lust feare imminent danger draw backe laboreth oftentimes procure glorie honor giuen cursed execrable misdemeanor imagining fansying himselfe dreames answerable agreeable desireth wherein resembleth mad men haue alwaies eies idea shape whichintemperate men resemble mad folk worke apprehension furie hold vision inward view troubleth diseased braine make vice intemperance odious vnto v moue v earnestly flie cause nourish labouring cut branch hurfull fruit bringeth superfluitie gluttony ambition pride excess kind delight wherof intreat particularly heerafter let v call mind example pernitious effect hath brought foorth voluntarily submitted themselues vnder hir tyrannous gouernment although search throughout ancient history yet hardly could alledge euidentheliogabalus testimonie life heliogabalus bicause kind cursed mischiefe detestable lust iniustice crueltie wherwith defiled yea fel furious frensie vice seeking become woman maried one minion thinking sexe better satisfie beastlines apparelled fashion neither man woman knowing impossible reason impietie corrupt life escape miserable end violent death ought rather haue vnto occasio amendment bewitched intemperance prepared poison ready hand poyson withall perceiued himselfe pressed enimies make death luxurious according desire kept poison vessel made precious stone prouided also silken halter hang withall saw expedient poisoned thinke better murder himselfe kept purpose kniues made precious mettals likewise caused high tower gilded built death fittest occasion offred meane gaue ouer execrable kind life god iust iudgement ended depriued mean wherwith desired serue owne turne death strangled souldiers gard trailed innero maner place citie rome nero one predecessor little better slew romane consul called atticus might haue free vse wife pleased himselfe much crueltie murderer vpon aram whatsoeuer desired necessarie life man superfluitie causeth many foolish excessiue expences amongst v besides ruine decaie many good house destruction bodie feared soule also doth ensue thereupon therefore erasmus said well nothing abiect hurtfull liue slaue pleasure mouth bellie achitob men saith plato addicted seruice belly care nothing foode mind like beast neuer enioy true get phisitions saith shortnes man life seneca cry life short art long complaint made nature bicause hath graunted beast liue fiue six age appointed short time life men borne many great thing haue smal time lose much time life long enough well imploied passeth away excesse negligence good done therein end constraint extreame necessitie although perceiue going yet feele gone moreouer man may reckon certaine inuentions meerely heathenish rather diuelish men commit reprobate action publike mask mummery libertie licence especially haue note well concerneth mask mummery common amongst v cause infinite offence forasmuch face appointed ordeined god seen openly mouth speake destroy ordinance god much lieth v become contrary vnto take vnto v false face depriue selues speech may sayd manie enimie delight pleasure commandeth v rather suffer cruell dolorous death start aside dutie certaine placeth chiefe good pleasure hath regard thing priuate profit whereby declareth sufficiently careth principall end action bicause naturally desire pleasure shun griefe easie v shew ignorance guideth depriued knowledge good wished pleasant acceptable seeke euill choice greatest mischiefe meane pleasure vnseparably followed griefe men labour eschew let v see pleasure ispleasure fruites bringeth hir voluptuousnes pleasure saith cicero properly called delight mooueth tickleth sences slideth slippeth away part leaueth behind occasion rather repentance calling remembrance many wicked vnnecessarie pleasure haue fallen intogreat disease receiued great loss suffred many reproches alwaies goeth alone alwaies accompanied sorow griefe pleasure saith plutark resolueth men body mollifieng daily delight continuall vse mortifieth vigor dissolueth strength whence abundance disease proceedeth pock osey life taketh away vnderstanding darkeneth memorie prophet osey saith taketh away hart moreouer odious whoredome ought vnto v much named amongst v onely curse laid vpon god ought sufficiently persuade v seeing thereby condemneth temporall eternall death haue besides many goodlie sentence notable example ethnicks pagan namely iust punishment part followed detestable vice hard heeles ought stir v vp hate flie might especially adulterie ioined therwith effect end concupiscencethe sacred knot mariage violated broken concupiscence saith aristotle changeth men body breedeth madnes soules end thereof luxuriousnes whence proceede thousand wrong violence incest murder poisoning innumerable impiety signe great loosenes basenes mind man subiect himselfe carnall concupiscence disordered desire contrarie reason whose office practise chuse euill good let v heere giue eare socrates disputation enthydemus fit present matter socrates disputation incontinencietell euthydemus doest thou thinke libertie good great profitable possession whether belongeth either man citie verie great therefore whosoeuer serueth pleasure vnbrideled desire bodie loue cannot execute knoweth good doest thou thinke free may thou iudgest thing woorthy free man able put practise whatsoeuer taketh good contrarywise hindred seruile slauish thou beleeuest incontinent men free yea truly iustly thinkest thou incontinent men hindred fro honest compelled commit vicious thing thinke much compelled one hindered practising maisters doest thou thinke forbid well constraine men embrace euill good truth wicked doest thou thinke bondage others troublesome one serueth wicked naughtie maisters yea incontinent men others miserable estate condition soeuer besides neuer thinketh vpon goodnes seeketh mean fulfill vntamed desire pleasure lust hath vse reason beast haue wise philosopher teacheth v sufficiently hurtfull pernitious thing suffer desire flesh raigne v considering draw v vehemently practise owne destruction especially fruit whoredomwhoredom bringeth kind mischiefe dissolueth weakneth body offendeth vertues good soule hir commeth men abase themselues lowe submit body soules inconstant vnrulie desire foolish woman see men bewitched harlot neede commaund hazard honour credit oftentimes make themselues example whole country vpon open scaffold labor couer folly goodly name loue better termed euripides name furie madnes men true good loue fountain friedship alwais grounded vpo vertue tendeth ende slipperie loose loue desire founded vpon opinion good deede pernitious euil adulterie follow vp miserable effect adulterieaccording aristotle curious inquirie another man loue vice two fold detestable wicked bicause committeth seeketh dutie nature take away another man honor reputatio spoileth accounteth precious namely loue friendship wife breaketh peace house causeth wife loose hir soule otherwise peraduenture would haue yeelded corrupted hir word cause infinite misery offence daily see come passe amongthe auncients vice odious narowly sought chasticed grieuous punishment much iulius caesar caused one captain beheaded bicause dishonoured mistresse house lodged staying vntill one accused without complaint made vnto hir husband law among zaleucus law adulteriethe locrians established zaleucus condemned conuicted vice adulterie haue eye puld lawe afterward well kept sonne taken fact people intreating zaleucus would neuer suffer punishment thing lessened yet satisfie importunitie sort caused one another sonnes eye plucked chusing rather beare halfe punishment allotted offence remaine vnpunished law law lulia adulterersviolated augustus caesar made law iulia intituled adultery wherein declared processe ought proceed attainted conuicted thereof punished euen permit father kill daughter taken fact adulterer fabius fabritius slain wife trecherie ende might haue greater libertie commit adulterie one yonger son whe came age slew mother adulterer absolued therof senate read also punishment adulterer vsed among egyptiansthat lest punishment vsed egyptian adulterer cut womas nose priuy part man briefly shall find nation honor ciuilitie neuer little regarded vice adulterie hath grieuously punished greatly hated noble mind herein example alexander alexander hated adulterieis woorthy remembred woman brought vnto one euening demanded hir came late answered stayed vntill hir husband gone bed sooner heard sent hir away angry men bicause almost caused commit adultery would much touch friend concubine although loued hir tooke wonderfully cassander true glory honor shal receiue shame keeper vertueslesse profit learne wherein ought feare shame dishonor aram saith cicero certain shame bashfulnes temperance gardian vertues deserueth great commendation also goodly ornament whole life fashioneth according patern decencie honestie achitob two thing saith plato wel able direct life liue vertuously namelie shame dishonest thing desire thing good vertuous let v therfore heare aser discourse amplie propounded vnto v aser see good ground although fat fertill bringeth foorth notwithstanding naughty wild plant good nature although endued many hath offended blusheth saith menander voyd good nature therefore shamefastnes nourished much made long remaineth man spirite good hope conceiued many haue shrunke feare shame reason torment could sort preuaile wicked saith euripides hath shame shamefastnes saith one ancient sister continencie companion chastitie yea mean hir societie fellowship chastitie greater safetie fault lessened shame made greater contention shame mollifieth hart iudge impudencie prouoketh anger touched quicke sharpe reprehension reformation maners yet nothing restrayned thereby full sweate blushing shame causeth heate ascend face euery one well borne remaineth inflexible vnmooueable smiling iesting thereat one say giueth great argument blockish senceles nature ashamed nothing reason long custome sinne naturall manconfirmation euill sinne saith diodorus athenian thing naturally ingrafted men neither euer law rigorous could staie course thereof although new paine punishment dailye added offence see men might bee drawne vice feare gather boldnes pouertie others rich become insolent ambitious couetous others haue passion occasion mooue induce ill turne aside make fruitles better way deepely imprint must auoid represse sinnein soules feare perpetuall shame infamie inseparable companion wickednes corrupt dealing often commit fault frailtie must togither repentance imprint memorie long remembrance thereof yea must lay often eies also shame dishonor might haue ensued thereof vnto v end afterward may better kept backe aduised like matter heerin let v follow example wayfaring men haue stumbled stone pilot haue brused ship rocke mindfull mishap life time greatly afraid onely stone rock cause euils also resemble prohibition notable custome among romanes aulus gellius writeth yoong romane dare enter strumpet house face couered fell man shameles come place vncouered seuerely punished committed forced adulterie truly one ashamed hath offended hope well amendment shame euill seruing bridle vice commendable shame wherein want prudence wisedome beareth sway euil hurtfull onely kind shame hurtfullare touched therewith oftentimes procureth great euils comminalties commonwealth whereof men haue great experience liue vnder gouernors magistrats iudges foolish basenes cowardlines mind either feare displease greatest blamed reprooued ignorant multitude bow bend another man becke right ignorant fellow seeke stay keepe thee discoursing vaine redious matter afraid rid thy selfe tell freely another time thou maist come visite hauing time leasure keepe companie longer thy friend man communicate thee act purpose wherein thou knowest somewhat though neuer little reprehended tell thereof hardly man importunate thee request intreaties neuer promise thou art able performe blush sort honestly refuse depart breake speake freely submit selues comelie manner man lightly complaine v blame v vpon slender occasion shall readie way accustome selues ashamed matter greater waight necessarie preseruation dutie otherwise afraid put backe glasse wine one acquaintance drinking doth offer vnto v howe resist request prince much commandement importunate suite whole people vniust brought vp youth persian youth instructedsuch sort neither spake thing dishonest putting death stripped starke naked presence another yea iudged euery vnciuill action litle soeuer committed others great wickednes parthian would neuer suffer wiues come among feastes least wine cause doe speake dishonest thing presence hippocratides walking hippocratides saying yong man blushedmet yong man wicked man company perceiuing began blush said thus vnto sonne thou must goe cause thee blush good cheere thou maiest yet repent thee blind eutichus set without aray battel eutichusby leonidas ashamed leaue fellowes danger caused slaue lead place fought wonderfully endeuor slain roman shamefast amongst themselues shamefastnes romanesthat father would bathe himselfe sonne sonne law father law greatly day worke fortitude chap aser man endued reason seeking imitate asmuch lieth author albeit simply absolutely standeth neede thing whatsoeuer yet doth woonderfull workes without ceasing benefit creature feeleth himselfe touched quicke soule desire profit among whome liueth high great laudable laborious meanes fearing perill forcing paine moreouer meditating weighing dignitie immortalitie soule careth earthly mortal good standeth feare contrarie whether hauing hauing minde nothing lesse quiet neither doth thinke good vpon earth taken great rare excellency flowe third riuer offortitude third riuer honestie fountaine honesty whereof speake namely vertue fortitude cicero saith cannot forced force amana vertue saith seneca great able resist fight extreame misery propertie fortitude guideth noble nature hard difficult thing may attaine end iust deuices aram fortitude cause neither feare danger turne aside way vertue iustice plato saith lifteth vp mind attend excellent laudable execution whatsoeuer knoweth belong dutie honestie according place whereunto called also cause neuer taketh thing hand rashly pretence soeuer hath neither kept backe feare matter offer good occasion putting hand hazard imminent danger soeuer seemeth threaten according sentence socrates hardest thing ought taken hand executed greater constancie valure hart hath well prudently grounded enterprise temeritie boldnes excesse vertue two vice hurtfull soule infected holdeth much nature beast essence wherein created let v consider imperfection horror infamie followeth may zealous follow decent honest aser must take good heede saith cicero least feare peril commit thing may iustly argue v timorous fearfull withall must beware offer selues vnto danger without cause nothing foolish albeit greater disgrace iustly reproched cowardly faint hart especially youth called effeminate yet feare good turneth v away dishonest thing maketh man staied wel aduised cause ancient two kind last kind feare worketh wicked feare paine punishment appointed offence wherby bridle kept backe restrained presuming commit villanies damnable purpose first kind feare said good necessarie great token commendable vertuous nature good cause grounded vpon feare reproch infamie vpon desire effect whatsoeuer belongeth dutie one two last kind testifieth vile contemptible abiect nature wicked corrupt disposition plutark speaking good good fearefeare calleth one element ground vertue saying chieflie requisite necessarie haue authoritie ouer others ought feare rather practise euil receiue punishment bicause first cause latter onelie themselues manie wallow wickednesse neuer without recompense therefore prudent well aduised man ought haue feare alwaies ioined true loue godbefore eies meane childlike feare vnseparably ioined true loue owe common father beginning wisedome wherby induced honour looke much ancient pagan kept awe causeth v respect good countriegood feare much shall condemnation doubled despise dutie also profitable feare haue eie vnto good safetie countrie cause v faithfully discharge euery charge committed vnto v end incurre perpetuall shame infamie among good men causeth v feare onelie dishonor vnaduised counsel action account seemelie honorable blamed euil spoken well dooing alexander great said well become king phociongood feare made phocion desert valure chosen generall atheniens fiue fortie time saie would neuer counsell hinder vttermost power enterprise war would haue concluded alexander said although athenian would cast awaie themselues yet suffer doe bicause haue intent purpose taken vpon charge captain demosthenes persuaded warre said vnto people kill thee enter furie phocion replied naie kill thee antigonuswell wit antigonus second king macedonia declared benefit commeth good feare necessarie foresight wise experienced captaine warre retiring enimies came assaile told certaine fled answered cleane contrarie looke backe profit said feare taketh awaie memorie good effect euerie art industrie yea sometimes haue beene found faintharted soone feare seazed vpon gaue vp ghost beeing oppressed anie euill violence passion feare greefe fullie practise power grounded vpon false opinion euill sworne enimies rest tranquillitie gnawing consuming life rust doth steele yron neither feare without vnrulie desire immoderate ioie thing worldlie base contemptible whereupon soule continuallie carried hither thither pernicious immoderate passion depriue hir excellencie hir immortalitie attend mortall corruptible affection flesh alexander spake possessed feare said place strong nature situation fearefull men iudge safe enough therefore satyricall poet said verie well fortune alwayes maketh timorous men alwaies litle timorous men little although borne bigge stature yet small courage heart maketh much contemptible bringing foorth worse dangerous effect making vnwoorthy intermedling matter estate policie warre number among many history claudius caesarmention may heere reckon claudius first caesar faintharted baseminded blockish mother said often nature begun finished truly hartlesfellow one litlehart nothing el bodie onely afraid men hazard warres trouble sedition danger long voyage losse good disease dolor yea least discommodities aduersities befall men euent causeth vsually forget reason dutie also frighted dreames tremble sight vision credite false abusing spirit forlorne feare stand awe celestiall signes briefly vpon least occasion may vnwoorthie care prudent valiant mind fall oftentimes vexation spirite loose altogither become mad inraged insomuch many haue hastened forward owne hand end miserable day read mydas king phrygia troubled mydasand vexed certaine dreames grew desperate died voluntarily drinking bloud bull aristodemus also king messenians warre subiects happened dog howled like woolnes came passe reason certain herbe called dogsteeth growing altar home wherupon vnderstanding southsayers euill signe stroken feare conceit thereof slue himselfe cassius captaine cassiushad better hart answered chaldean astrologian counselled fight parthian vntill moone passed scorpio feare quoth scorpion archer hee spake bicause romane armie beene put worst plaine chaldea parthian archer neuertheles spake midas aristodemus seldome base mind stand great feare death griefefollowed yea rarely found amongst coward base minded fellowes commonly flie temporall death much may also griefe feare sort contemning vertue iustice labour nothing preserue liues togither carnall commodity obtaining seeme liue cleane without care soule hir portio world end togither bodie effect feare death sufficiently felt euerie one particular number verie small would willingly make say sluce conscience might deliuered thereof let v confesse selues fearefull faintharted boast fortitude generositie hart suffer v stand feare certaine death holie honest cause farre fearing forsaking dutie doubt vncertaine death speron rehearseth dialogue gentleman padua sufficiently sheweth maruellous force apprehension conceit death extendeth selfe onelie vpon spirites men also changeth nature body want constancie toa strange alteration gentleman haire one nightbeare sustaine small light griefe inioieng eternall good yoong gentleman put prison vpon accusation tolde certaintie head cut daie following newes altered sort one onelie night hee white greieheaded whereof shew appearance liued long time besides experience daily ministreth vnto v sufficient proofe mischiefes proceed want courage fainthartednes especially matter estate gouernment publike office wherein fearefull soft man euerie reproch dislike euill opinion world yea ignorant much least danger person feare threatnings greater sort yeeldeth easilie dutie suffereth himselfe drawne error wicked common sort middle lesser sort wherefore serue void ofagamemnon dispensed rich coward reason assurance homer saith king agamemnon dispensed rich coward going warre personally mare gaue wherein truly great reason bicause fearefull man hurteth much profiteth little onely warre euen euery good vertuous action caused great captaine paulus aemilius say magnanimitie courage part reuerenced euery enimie cowardlines although good successe yet alwayes men despised might mention sundry vice ordinarily growe nourished cowardlines pusillanimitie namely crueltie treason breach promise impatiencie idlenesse slouth couetousneswhat vice proceed cowardlines enuie backbiting iniustice hope sequele discourse offer v matter occasion handle vice particularly houre affording v time leasure enter vpon many thing togither remaineth yet word beof seruile feare spoken feare said accompany froward wicked many time called poet seruile feare onely horror punishment holdeth backe practising wicked purpose spake pythagoras sayd careth euill respect onely bicause would punished wicked although feare accursed condemned yet necessarie preseruation humane societie otherwise thing would run confusion shameles malice wicked earth full great deale better feare restrained wicked desire wils without feare abandon themselues put execution albeit way excusable god requireth serued hart spirit neuerthelesse feare doth alwayes stay putting malice effect retained much inflamed kindled desire satisfie corrupt end constrained burst foorth euidently shew mischiefe kept secret long time commo sort saith seneca staied lawes committing euil philosopher contrarywise hath reason lawes good bicause law commandeth abstaining fro euil bicause forbiddeth bicause knoweth one honest vile wicked hauing seene vice cleane contrary fortitude knowing euery vertue hath counterfeitof rashnesse effect thereof follower thereof doubt rashnesse vice falsly shrowdeth selfe vnder title fortitude valure vertue easily ouerthroweth selfe vnderpropped good counsaile greater abilitie supposeth haue selfe sooner turneth aside wickednesse prudence gouerne isocrates saith fortitude ioined prudence auaileable otherwise procureth euill good possessor thereof fortitude saith lactantius without necessarie constraint dishonest matter hazardeth hir selfe daungers chaungeth rashnesse doth anie thing aduentures saith aristotle consideringwho vertuous man well doth ought called vertuous onely put execution knowledge consultation election therefore noble acte make account vertue loue thereof feare losse life otherwise deare point rashnesse follie contemne life vpon small light occasion rashnesse causeth man ioy hart vaine friuolous matter cast himselfe certaine vndoubted daungers desire earnestly fall vndertake thing vnaduisedly vnconstrained expect peril knoweth fall vponcato elder cato hearing certaine men commend one openly desperately hazarded himselfe bold without discretion peril warre said vnto great difference betweene much esteeming vertue little waighing life would haue said commendable thing desire life vertuous truely liue die themselues good rightly good matter shunne death proceed faint hart reprehended rashnesse especiallie condemned captaines head army procureth great dammage kingdomesiphicrates comparison armie man bodie monarchy manie march vnder conduct iphicrates athenian captaine would haue v learne compared armie scoutes lightly armed handes horseman feete battaile footemen stomacke breast captaine head man bodie sayde captaine hazardeth himselfe much throweth himselfe daunger without cause retchlesse life onely also whose safetie dependeth vpon contrarywise taking care safegard owne person careth therewithall vnder isadas lacedemonianthe rashnesse isadas seeyng epaminondas thebane armie hand agaynst spartanes readie force take citie vnclothed himselfe starke naked puttyng shirte taking partisane one hand sworde went might mayne agaynst enemy shewed great prowesse valure behauiour although crowne giuen seignorie according custome amongst yet fined bicause hazarded lyfe rashly see daylie among v manie example great mischiefes befall men rashnesse led ambition desire vayneglorie therefore conclude drawe profite present discourse say ought feare incurring blame dishonour filthie vnhonest matter euill deed shun feare proceeding want courage pusillanimitie depraued corrupted nature last proper peculiar wicked maketh man vnapt good commendable thinges acte prudence fortitude prouide tempest stormes come shippe still hauen yet afrayd middest stormes point rashnesse man throw himselfe wittingly euident danger might auoyded without breach vertue iustice therefore plato saith timorous rash men feare enterprise vnaduisedly whatsoeuer take hand man may valiantbut noble mind thing prudence also seneca saith thou maist valiant thou cast thy selfe peril desirest fall timorous men neither abhorrest standest feare timorous following sage aduice cicero enterprise thing must onely consider whether honest commendable also whether like meane execute neither throgh cowardlines giue ouer greedie desire presumption purchase selues reputation rash men obseruing moreouer euery matter importance maxime estate begin thing must diligently prepare foresee whatsoeuer necessarie thereunto magnanimitie generositie chap aram saying aristotle cometh remembrance fortitude isa mediocritie fearing enterprising magnanimitie consisteth great thing somewhat troubled vnderstading sentece bicause semeth would put difference betweene fortitude magnanimitie latter excellencie perfection cause companion hauing intreated morning vertue fortitude propound vnto discourse vnto v magnanimitie achitob among mortall perishing thing nothing philosopher say ought trouble magnanimitie noble hart find propound vnto v word wisedome cannot remaineth life time subiect affection perturbation would haue true magnanimitie notwithstanding wel able bring foorth infinite wonderfull effect noble mind causing neuer vnprouided good resolution put execution according ouerthwarts happen vnto aser propertie noble spirit saith cicero turned aside ingratitude desire good men euen enemy also leaue carking mortall may imbrace celestiall thing shall vnderstand large thee amana marueilous effect work true magnanimitie amana although vertue fortitude neuer perfected without magnanimitie much magnanimitie issay generositie noblenes hart vndoubtedly comprehended vnder first part fortitude cicero calleth magnificence great excellent thing yet notwithstanding seemeth word magnanimitie carieth greater particular empasis man may say wonderful effect thereof appeare principally three point whereof purpose discourse first concerning magnanimitie consisteth three thingsextreme desperate matter man past hope sauing life wherein perfect magnanimitie always knoweth find conuenient remedie wise consolation suffering himselfe vexed therewith second respecteth dutie towards enimies generositie wise suffer man practise consent wickednesse vnder pretence euer aduantage may reaped thereby third causeth noble minded man contemne account thing vnworthy care soule others wonder labor mean obtaine namelie strength health beauty philosopher call good bodie good body fortuneriches honor glory say good fortune likewise stand feare contrary amongst woorthy famous men olde time whose name glorious factes crowned immortall lawrell ingrauen temple memorie find praise woorthie greater admiration ought awaken stirre v vp better christian dutie effect vertue magnanimitie vpon three occasion presently touched whereof one first effect magnanimitieeffect yeeld reason passe limit duty fainting vnder heauy burthen extreme distress horror death bringeth euen midst greatest agonie seemeth intollerable man iudgement shew grauitie woorthines depart sort peace quietnes soules constancie cheerefulnes spirit meditate vpon ioy hauen saluation behold eye soule whereinto happy death hand shall second effectshortly receiued another effect accomplish farre vniust matter point iniustice vsurpe power sauing liues like lord ouer whome hath right command many speech philosophie vsed standing much vpon stoicall opinion onely wise opinion stoicks good man free wicked men bond men slaues went alone chamber slew himselfe sword sylla dictator hauing condemned death inhabitant perouza pardoning none host also would needes die saying would hold life liberally free bondage brother countreymen praise conquering enemy neither might money obtaine leaue posteritie men alwaies say vniust wicked haue ouerthrowne good men vsurpe tyrannous rule dominion euil one kind another whereby seemeth philosopher delighted painting picture patience neuer shal among men except first vnclothed humaine nature become blockish sencelesse stone long man remaineth
