mind vnder yoke obedience iust rightfull god certain expectation thing promised causeth v iudge impatiencie contumacie rebellion diuine wil definition patienceand sufficient selfe make man called wretched patience saith plato habite consisteth sustaining stoutly labour griefes loue honestie law saith good thing keep tranquillitie spirit much may aduersities complaine vncertaine bicause men know whither light vpon good euil also bicause sorow helpe come rather hindreth curing euill lastly bicause nothing humane matter wherof great account made must need support desire labour nobly honestly courageously skilleth endure endure doth patience preuail know whatsoeuer haue done executed v godlines sake conflict fruit patienceof patience saith euripides vanquished better vanquisher let v thinke calamitie cannot sustained nature man armed patience inuincible tower patience saith cicero voluntarie long suffring labour calamity trauels difficult matter loue honestie vertue thing ouerthrowen counsaile wil good one remedy beare patiently whatsoeuer shall come vpon v patience serueth v meane attaine great matter staying men fainting danger trauels patience whatsoeuer disordred may brought againe good order wise emperor marcus aurelius would giue v vnderstand sayd patience lesse holpen gouernmet estate knowledge likewise part followed curtesie gentlenes make well liked adorned therewith sooner draw good wil cause men obedience force violence doth slowe anger saith wise man better mightie man prou ruleth owne mind better winneth citie true patience loueth affliction suffreth causing possesseth hir giue prayse god midst aduersities submit iudgement pressed disease neither pouertie keep backe comending highly bountie goodnes short pearle sheweth hir beautie euen midst puddle patient man causeth vertue appeere al aduersities moreouer patience shew aduersities mooueth compassion pitie see v suffer thing greatly comforteth affliction oftentimes causeth others reape inestimable benefite behold v suffer vniustly serueth awaken strengthen weake knowledge duetie suffer themselues deceiued poisonfull sweetnes worldly good commodity word vertue patience necessarie good happy life part action man life guided proper end without hir branch magnanimitie fortitude greatnes courage impatiencie weakenes imbecillitie impatiencie choler wrathbase vile contemptible nature wherin choler end wrath easily ingendred two pernitious passion soule differ nothing furie elder cato said onely continue lesse time longer definition anger possidonius teacheth v saying anger nothing else short furie aristides called inflammation blood alteration hart cicero saith latines call anger named grecian desire reuenge solon demanded whome man fraught anger might compared answered maketh account losing friend careth although procure enemy himselfe besides saying sage experience sufficiently sheweth v choler anger enemy reason plutark saith lesse proud presumptuous vneasie guided another great mightie tyrannie insomuch ship giuen ouer mercie windes stormes would sooner selfe receiue pilot without man caried headlong wrath choler would yeeld reason admonition another angry man like burne themselues within owne house filleth soule sort trouble chafing noise neither seeth heareth thing would profit vnles make prouision long time succour himselfe reason studie wisedome whereby may able ouerthrow impatiency choler argue accompanie giuen impatiencie cholermost part weake effeminate hart true see woman commonly sooner driuen choler men sicke sound olde yoong vitious gluttonous iealous vaineglorious ambitious men vnfainedly hate vice whereby euident enough choler proceedeth infirme weake part soule generositie thereof neither doth make saying alleadge opinion aristotle al peripateticks maintained ought moderate affection passion soule otherwise necessarie pricke men forward vertue yea aristotle said choler whetstone sharpen set edge vpon fortitude generositie aristotle contrary opinion stoicksthe academicks stoicks contend greatly opinion namely cicero seneca say forasmuch choler vice cannot cause vertue seeing two contrary thinges haue nothing common together considering fortitude proceedeth aduised consultation election reason perfecteth worke whereas choler hindreth troubleth sort angrie man cannot deliberate possible stand steed performance excellent action inuincible reason bicause vertue commeth vice end philosophie man know vice meanes deliuer himselfe seeing infamie discommoditie accompanie impatiencie choler cannot knowne vnto v yea notwithstanding common amongst v perfectest infected therewith let v looke helpe meane cure impatiencie choler may curedour selues thereof first let v know although men may mooued wrath choler diuers cause yet vnto opinion contemned despised commonly ioined therefore true soueraigne remedie may auoid cold slender occasion entring choler neighbour altogither vnbeseeming loue owe put v much may suspition despised contemned brauerie boldnes lay fault either vpon necessitie negligence vpon chance vntowardnes lacke discretion ignorance want experience oftentimes offend v seeme strict counsell hard practise yea hatefull many frenchman chiefly nobilitie curious preseruation honour title would disguise desire worldly glory whervnto wicked iudge patiencethey shew themselues much affectionated testifie sufficiently neuer knewe wherein true honor consisteth separated vertue shadowe bodie also know patience accounting rather fainthartednes cowardlines part daughter vertue fortitude generositie yea iudging dishonor man contumeliously handled render like againe contrariwise know support indure wrong iniurie patiently euen haue meanes reuenge selues note absolute noble excellent vertue yea beseemeth christian one hath word scripture well leuit deut hart thou shalt auenge mindfull wrong child thy people shalt loue thy neighbour thy selfe lord vengeance recompence mine hope heerafter shall discourse subiect itselfe deserueth handled whereof choler bredlargely following therefore matter must vnderstand choler bred custome angrie small thing afterward becommeth easilie fire sudden wrath reuenging bitternes vntractable sharpenes making man froward furious disliking euery thing wherefore wise man ought presently oppose iudgement reason euery little anger suppresse helpe make soule firme power resist beate backe fiercenes choler matter greater weight consequence nourisheth anger beginning inflameth himselfe may easily auoid least scatter good way remedie cholerit moreouer great meane ouercome choler obeye giue credite vnto first instant wherin beginneth appeere imitating socrates therein whensoeuer felt himselfe somwhat egerly mooued man ought like wise pilote getteth himselfe vnder lee rocke let fall voyce gently shewyng smiling countenance curteous looke thereby setting himselfe directly passion besides wil greatly helpe v mooued anger stay toong certaine space delay litle owne reuenge certaine man promiseth speaketh doth many thing anger afterward wisheth neuer thought vnto fitly agreeth counsaile athenodorus taking counsaile hast cause thinke thy selfe happie measure burthen saith martial may well beare common complaint men estate condition custome also ioined lay cause suffer vpon cruell intollerable destinie accusing imperfectionto excuse owne fault wherefore cannot aptly compare blind folk angrie oftentimes call blind vnawares meete iustle desire cure soules many miserable passion depriue v true rest cross vnpatiently first let v heare notable opinion good ill hapsundry notable opinion many ancient men touching good ill hap thou knowest ought knowen thing said pythagoras thou art happy let accounted happy said homer fortune hath equally wayed good euill greatest miserie said bias able beare miserie man happie said dionysius elder hath learned youth vnhappy beare yoke better whereunto hath subiect accustomed long tyme demetrius surnamed besieger said iudged none vnhappy neuer tasted aduersitie would haue sayd sure argument fortune iudged base abiect deserued busie hir selfe man man commaund humble quarellous quiet tyrant iust cruel pitifull coward hardie ignorant skilfull greatest thieues hang innocent meane may doubt whether happiest good rather wicked happines according ancient truth perfected good notable reason shew worldly thing called good happines cannot perfected thing thing certain whosoeuer enioieth al good thing shall perfectly happy nothing called good profitable contrary euill whatsoeuer may one euill good ought called good moreouer must possession firme stedfast permanent good maketh man happy nothing ought wax old perish decay thing wherin happy life consisteth seeing feareth loose cannot sayd liue quietly therefore neither beautie strength disposition body neither rich glory honour pleasure truely called good seeing oftentymes cause many euils waxe old vanish away many time soone man hath receiued lastly worke v vnsatiable desire many men thing haue occasion euill call good possessed abundance cannot yet keep owner thereof vnhappy miserable wherfore may say happines cannot perfected possession humane mortall thing neither vnhappines want wherein true happines consisteththe true felicitie ought desire world consisteth good soule nourished hope vnspeakable euerlasting happines promised assured vnto second life vnhappysay none vnhappy reason peruersnesse feele conscience doubting expectation eternall promise also giue ouer themselues vice whose nature corrupt destroy infect venom alwayes thing whereof taketh hold common misery man life cannot sort make vnhappy whose naturall disposition maners beyng framed decked vertue able giue impart euery condition life whether poore rich prosperous aduerse honourable contemptible happinesse ioy pleasure contentation flowe soule aboundantly fountaine liuelie spring philosophie hath discouered vnto fertile field grace science whereby enioyeth true tranquillitie rest spirit much man may haue mortall life moderating perturbation soule commaunding ouer vnpure affection flesh shoe turneth fashion foote contrarywise happinesse man commeth within himso inward disposition wise moderate man causeth lead life like vnto mild peaceable quiet neuer caried away vnreasonable passion bicause neuer enioyeth reioyceth immoderately hath vseth well put hand without feare repining taken away following therein saying democritus whosoeuer mindeth liue alwayes happilie must propound himselfe desire thing possible content thing present therefore seeing fountaine felicitie contentation life within v let v cure cleanse diligently perturbation seeke hinder tranquillitie spirites ende externall thing come without v agaynst expectation may seeme vnto v friendly familiar know vse wel plato compared life tableplay wherein life compared tableplaydice must chance wel plaier must vse wel dice shal cast two point euent lot dice power receiue mildly moderatly falleth vnto v dispose euerie thing place may either profite good least hurt bad power belongeth dutie wise men fortune saith plutarke may well cast sickenesse take away good bring disgrace people make wicked coward slouthfull baseminded enuious honest aliaunt nobleminded take setled temperate disposition prudence maketh iudge tedious grieuous troublesome thing befall grounded vpon vanishing good vpon philosophicall sentence firme discourse reason may say haue preuented thee fortune haue closed vp thy chance stopped wayes entrance vpon led ioyfull life long vertue part proper man strongest peraduenture great inconuenience happen vnto hope humaine power able ouercome ioy spirite considereth hauen safetie hand wherein may saue himselfe swimming body skiffe leaketh departing boldly without feare misery world may enioy absolute perfectalexander crate opposed one otherhappines alexander great hauing vnder dominion halfe world heard philosopher anaxarchus dispute maintaine innumerable world began weepe saying haue good cause sorowful mourne infinite number world seeing yet haue able make selfe lord one crate philosopher brought vp schoole wisdome hauing stead wealth old cloke scrip neuer wept life always seen mery passing ouer dayes cheerfully two kind life contrary one appeereth sufficiently within selues outward thing wherein must seeke foundation certaine ioy watered flourisheth strength remembrance good vertuous action proceeding soule guided rightagamemnon knowledge reason homer bringeth agamemnon complaining greatly bicause command great part world intollerable burthen vpon shoulder whereas diogenes sold slaue lying along mocked sergeant cried sale would rise vp commanded scoffingly said vnto thou wart sell fish wouldest thou make arise cry rather man want maister buy serue turne well wherby may fitly note happines rest contentation man dependeth vertue onely worldlie greatnes glorie reason selfe diogenes beholding stranger come lacedemonia curiously decked festiuall day woont said vnto doth honest man thinke euery day festiuall vnto truly nothing ought mooue v much shew outward signes ioy breedeth serenitie calmenes tempestuous waues humane misery calamity haue soule pure cleane wicked deedes wils counsel manner vndefiled troubled infected vice acknowledging estate mortall corruptible thing iudge vnwoorthie care soules may wholy lift vp contemplation heauenlie eternall thing wherein happines perfect felicitie consisteth heereby learne second life onely seeke andwhere must seeke true happines expect fruition true happines neuer increase diminished man make line straighter straight nothing iust iust happie happie otherwise vntill man gotten might desire would neuer setled man called happie felicitie perfect selfe cicero knew well enough said man standing feare great thing could happie respect man liuing speake deed happie life perfect absolute end therefore may reape profit present discourse let v neuer thinke man may called happie vnhappie bicause aduanced disgraced honor good worldlie commodity bicause partaker either prosperitie aduersitie compas hath thing according hart desire neither thing much cast downe sooner discouraged man afflicted misseth purpose mindes resolute constant enough slipping beside themselues beyond limit reason couetousnes ouertaken gluttonie lift vp desire worldlie glorie imperfection happen commonly vpon whome fortune much fawneth felicitie saith seneca hath beene hurt cannot indure one blow hath long continuall combat discommodities hath hardued selfe suffering bearing iniuries doth suffer selfe ouercome euill one greatest benefit man may haue life neither changed aduersitie lift vp prosperity well rooted tree although shaken sundrie wind yet ouerthrowne truly ridiculous commeth worldly thing ordinarie naturall course euen sequele cause linked togither depending one another changing estate mortall thing haue power alter make mutation reason wisedom ought abide stedfast mind man cause plato said nothing vertue could tame men furnished therewith behaued themselues constantly courageously alwaies poore needie cause libertie wise man soule knoweth nature externall good belonging life neuer troubled care assured plutark saith apparell giueth heate man staieth keepeth naturall heate proceedeth man himselfe hindring dispersing aire man liueth happily contentedly bicause compassed whence happines contentation commeth much wealth tranquillitie ioy rest proceed within soule heape vp saith philosopher store gold gather siluer togither build faire gallery fill whole house full slaues whole towne thy debtor yet thou doest maister passion thy soule thou quenchest thy vnsatiable desire deliuerest thy soule feare carking care thou doest asmuch procure thy quietnes thou gauest wine one ague life selfe saith plato ioyfull vnles care chased away causeth v waxe grayheaded whilest desire meane store rich superfluous desire hauing alwaies gnaweth hart whereupon commeth passe oftentimes amongst men see great madnes coueting moniepouertie better rich death life truly great madnes greedy coueting monie touched maladie follow rich zeale supposed gotten euill come neere also set light haue burne desire hauing shall call good hath end measure gotten beginning desire haue horse saith epictetus said better bicause hath eaten another bicause hath gilt harnesse bicause stronger swifter better made euery beast accounted according vertue shall man esteemed according rich ancestor aboue others beyng withdrawen care gouernment many earthly thing feele themselues much rauished speciall heauenly grace hinder meditation contemplation celestiall thing whence may easily draw great assured contentation life certaine hope shall enioy perfectly bicause prepareda pretie comparison blessed immortalitie second life nothing certaine sunne great deale better seene cleare cleane water eternallmatth life thouwilt perfect saith sell thou hast giue poore thou shalt haue treasure heauen adding besides rich man shall hardly enter kingdome heauen father diuiding substance among child leaue one eldest best beloued enioying principall mannor inheritance rest mother good much lesse value terme life folly iudge last preferred andno comparison worldlie heauenlie treasure better portion shewed happines felicitie wealth adde rich men aboue poorer sort accounted miserable wretched take away saith lactantius insolencie boasting rich men difference betweene poore man rich made condition one prouideth nourishment vnreasonable creature doth distribute vnto v much knoweth eternall prescience foreknowledge needfull v whereof shall complaine except inheritor damnable vice ingratitud first able make v partaker life without doubt found thousand time happie rich pouertie saith aristophanes mistres manner pouertie said archesilaus seemeth sharpe hard troublesome nurse good linage pouertie equall rich thou desirest many thing little seeme thee great pouertie said anaximenus maketh spirite sharpe men excellent thing belonging life good mistres knowledge skill life poore men said aristonymus like nauigation made alongst shore sea life rich men maine sea first sort may easily cast anchor come shore saue themselues whereas others cannot bicause owne power fortune flie pouertie said hipsaeus iniustice wrong man euer punished bicause poore many bicause vniust neither man life commended bicause rich bicause iust hunger saith plutark neuer engendreth adult erie want monie lust pouertie short kind temperance thou wert borne among persian said epictetus thou wouldest wish dwell grecia liue happie estate art thou foole bicause thou seekest rather liue happily pouertie seeing thou art borne therein striue great labor rich thou maist liue better lie downe little bed health great large bed sicke great deale better liue rest little wealth trauell care aboundance neither pouertie procureth trouble rich driueth away feare reason causeth men neither desire rich feare pouertie thing saith bion wise could speake aswell licenced dispute v might pouertie iustly say vnto v manner excellent defence pouertie man wherefore fightest thou art thou become enemie haue robbed thee thing haue beene cause thou hast receiued iniurie haue depriued thee good thing haue taken thee either prudence iustice fortitude thou fearest least necessarie thing faile thee way full herb fruit fountaines water hast thou many bed earth great many couerlets mattress leaues hast thou good cooke meanes maketh good sauce thee hunger thirst doth take great pleasure drinking doest thou thinke man shall die hunger bicause hath tart thirst haue delicate wine cooled snow thing delicacie nicenes doest thou want house many goodly church city answer could made pouertie speake thus truly hath vertue possesseth good bicause alone maketh men happie may spoken aswell poore man rich sayd thales beare end must farre hating enimie rather thinke selues beholding bound vnto great good procureth vnto v one propertie vice make v ashamed enimies haue committed fault ourwhy men beholding enimies friend take enimie spie enuier life imperfection raigne v wil freely giue v vnderstand thereof hateth v slacke publish euery reason plutarke calleth enimie schoolemaster costeth v nothing learne may curious obseruers ready defender honor vttred presence bicause say cannot offended spoken absence speake auouch slander face raysed behind backes according weake reason would haue men iudge reproch iniurie either credite discredite according power truth fact selfe requireth whereupon also passe ouer without profite amendment life knew misliked others vpon bare report made vnto thinke themselues greatly misused harmed spake ill presently purpose auenged herein agree al man voluntarily offereth iniurie another would haue sword presently decide controuersie say iniurie nay yea nay forthwith thinke lie giuen outfaced nothing death one together oftentimes dearest best friend able thinke repaire preiudicate supposed offence vaine honour world detestable furie found cruel beast spare bloud sexe conuenient time lost reproouing self odious cannot much named shame trembling horror man dull vnderstanding knoweth murder forbiddenthat effusion bloud forbidden god outrage sort permitted much lesse may christian forget himselfe farre kill another except necessitie defending owne body seruice prince country iust warre amongst sententious saying socrates wise wonderfull workes plato scholer find none diuine woorthie greater praise sentence often repeated reuenge sort notable sentence vsed iust said socrates offend although offred v wrong good man neuer ought euil yea great deale better suffer offer contumelie slaine slay bicause one bringeth detriment man soule procureth vtter ruine destruction therof sound ill many men eares iudge without passion eies see eares vnderstand end calling also reason true prudence generositie taught v studie philosophie doubt would subscribe opinio wise philosopher agreeing well taught v spirite god condemneth murderer offereth leuit iniurie another calleth himselfe psal defender innocencie one returneth matth reward recompence suffer righteousnes equitie may therfore doubt farre better receiue euil killed kill seeing one good houre perpetuall rest felicitie hastened forward vtterly frustrated thereof throwen hell eternall fire endeuor shew forth effect true magnanimitie greatnesse hart doubt beare endure al modestie suffer iniurie patiently badge absolute vertueand patience outrage wrong enimies marke vertue absolute perfect doth appeere vertue consisteth difficult thing vertue commeth neerest diuine nature hardest obtained least familiar men woorthie beseeming noble valiant man rest vnto may attribute better marke vertue patience whereof haue alreadie intreated see man vpon earth base estate woman feeble weake liuing creature litle striken reuenge themselues willingly wel greatly ought vertue accounted forceth natural lust reuenge bred al liuing creature noble must mind man need able master violent passion common men thereby procuring selfe name mild gratious spirit readie forgiue proper peculiar diuine nature therfore great monarch alexander said man wronged need noble hart forgiue enimie tha reueged kil behold saying noble prince euer earth bare courtier time say contrarie great vertue saith epictetus hurt thou commendable kind reuenge art misused commendable thing pardon thou mightest hurt praisewoorthie kind reuenge let go peace ouercome therefore pittacus sage hauing one power dealt contumeliously suffered depart vnharmed saying pardon better reuenge one proper spirit man cruel beast although onely respect benefit life ought shunne motion iniurie desire reuenge forasmuch cannot either determine execute thousand perturbation cause v want rest tranquillitie soules wherein happinesse felicitie consisteth good counsaile senecaand therfore seneca saith wronged thee weaker thou forgiue mightier spare thy selfe whosoeuer nourisheth neighbor anger whosoeuer prouoketh incenseth seeth vehement importunate committeth two fault first hateth himselfe procuring owne trouble griefe secondly brother bicause maketh must nothing cholerhim sad vexeth moreouer prudent men theophrastus saith ought doe nothing choler vnreasonable part soule mooued foreseeth nothing wisely driuen forward contentious desire suffereth selfe caried hither thither drunken also must take great heed alwaies put execution whatsoeuer haue mind vnto onely moderate reason commandeth v wherein shal deserue praise true magnanimity say command selues vehemencie choler driueth men forward auenged enimies act sauoureth vile abiect hart drawing neere brutish fiercenes noble mind despiseth whatsoeuer earthlie mortall vading may thinke nothing heauen immortalitie studie philosophie teacheth v euen expert phisitions knowe draw medicine apt preseruation life serpent poison deadly venemous thing ought draw apt similltu lefrom enimies life ought onely power god iustice profit commoditie backbitings reproches iniuries easily done make small account man may profit backbiting enimiestheir intent consider narrowly fact speake ill end guiltie condemn v may purge correct selues harme v wrongfully impudencie cause reproches iniuries turned back sent themselues togither shame dammage thought procure vnto v wheras shall lesse honest vertuous men best reuenge honorable victorie carie away enimies best kind reuengsurpasse diligence bountie magnanimitie goodturnes vertuous action whereby wil sooner perceiue confesse selues vanquished constrained stop mouth represse toong force oppose may say enterprised kill prometheus thessalien gaue great blowe sword vpon apostume put danger death lancing saued life contrary meaning iniurious speech enimies vttred wrath ill hurt v haue cause curing many euils v whereof made account making v much better bicause iniurie seemeth hard vneasie tolerated imbecillitie man nature soone offended hart man full reuenge let v yet see whether find remedie cure incurable least wise purge clense many wayes may receiue iniuriethe accident euil iniurie offered either good honour person man touching first last namely spoiling good violence offred person reuenge either lawe god man haue repulse force force meane constrained thereunto else way prince iustice open euery one haue robbed thee must thou become thiefe satisfie thy selfe thine owne strength much lesse oughtest thou set thy selfe faultie many thou weaker art ouertaken hurt wronged oughtest thou vse new force violence murder reuenge thy selfe repaire thy iniurie receiued sword hand king magistrate representeth person belongeth onely vse trouble publike tranquillitie ciuil societie end shew either would durst meddle soueraigntie whose greatnesse preseruation consisteth administration iustice yea lawes haue alwaies abhorred violence priuate force haue restored men must take law owne hand although rightly executedthieues robber place vniustly possessed driuen violence man say thing ought deed dulie considered iustice executed forsaken earth dwell heauen canst thou execute seeing thou art called demand iustice tarie iust iudge wil returne double hath vniustly taken thee thou hast suffered hath denied thee euen thou shalt haue greater neede thy day short thou shalt liue euer thou hast reaped poore miserable life concerning honor iniurie whereof offence done honorfeare let v know cannot hurt good man bicause vertue inuincible protecteth defendeth day fetch farre haue honor tied vaine opinion world reiecteth contemneth men coward baseminded haue put vp least iniurie offered another honoreth noble courageous lustilie kill enimies cause many would willingly forget iniurie receiued dare loue friend also bicause see would rather imputed vnto toke faint hart desire nature happines life care greatly come vnto let v socrates void reuengeare better instructed imitate socrates counselled reueng wrong receiued made answer mastie bit asse giuen blow would haue serue mooued mocksof nature much lesse ought prouoked stirred vp laughter gibing cannot touch offend troubled caried away passion thus much socrates wisely giue one vnderstand told certaine mocked quoth thinke mocked heereupon remember notable answer made one ptolemaeus ptolemaeusking egypt counselled punish grammarian king demanding way gibing father peleus made answer desired first knowe lagus father noting thereby king borne base parentage vnseemly quoth ptolemaeus friend king mocked also vndecent mocke another although dutie tread vnder foote desire reuenge make account iniuries mock yet lawfull man may repulse mockefor v sometime disposed greater offence arise thereof stop mouth iniurious impudent little short replie wrath choler certaine meekenes graue smiling somewhat nippingly reproches freely suffer ease man offereth thee wrong iniurie delight neither hearing vttering likewise demosthenes answered another demosthenesthis sort enter combat thee wherein vanquished better note many way man may vniustthis many way guiltie iniustice deny neighbour duty owe vnto vocation requireth v also seeke inrich selues hinderance whether openly sinister suttle meanes christian sinceritie ought shine dealing let v see ancient hated vice spake pernitious effect thereof man saith socrates ought commit vniust act small soeuer treasure wealth profit may hope reape thereby bicause treasure earth compared least vertue soule cause men iointly ought haue one end intent profit themselues also beneficiall euery one men haue respect owne vnitie would soone dissolued although said cato iniustice procure perill doth practise yet would others plato calleth corruption soule ciuill sedition neuer looseth strength haue onely within themselues causeth wicked man variance within himselfe vrgeth troubleth turmoileth continually vntill haue plunged gulfe vice whereupon afterward easily ouerfloweth impietie caring thing satisfie vnbrideled desire fall haue sword hand correct iniustice either authorize practise themselues gate misery opened vpon euery one vnrulie licence wicked wallow kind crueltie whence disorder confusion proceedeth vtter ruine finall subuersion according money came crownes purposed go rome warre parthian would needes know much wealth came first offred hercules tenth good secondly made publike feast people rome thousand table thirdly gaue euerywonderfull rich citizen much wheate would finde three moneths notwithstanding found worth talent amounted foure million two hundred threescore thousand crownes vsed say accounted man rich except therefore enuie griefe arising another man prosperitie malignitie commonlymalignitie defined effect malice one man beareth another ioined whether fountaine therof say one part thereof others haue malignitie delight pleasure take another man harme although receiue profit thereby seemeth accidentall procured hatred ill arising euill affection one man beareth another cause plutark distinguisheth hatred enuie saying hatred bred hart imaginationthe difference betweene hatred enuie conceit haue whome hate behaueth himselfe wickedly either towards men generally particularly towards v men enuie onely whome know prosperitie seemeth enuie indefinite limited much like sore eies offeded euery cleernes light hatred limited alwaies grounded staied vpon certaine obiects regard selfe moreouer man hath iust cause enuie another man prosperitie doth man wrong bicause happie whereas contrarie side many iustly hated vice impiety oughtto hate wicked propertie good man shunned good men hatred wicked proceed counsell man aristotle saith fortune casuall accidental cause thing purposely done certaine end haue apparant cause falling otherwise man may well say thing came fortune falleth besides thought vndertaketh worke deliberation epicurus said fortune cause agreed neither person time manner theophrastus speaking fortune saith looketh whereat shooteth oftentimes delighteth taking away rest yeeres assurance quietnes priuate man passe repasse italy without gard euen midst whome much offended read also mithridates king pontus wrote vnto concerning war vndertaken saying maruelled sylla durst buckle great fortune especially knowing deceiued time whereas neuer knew sylla consul returned answer selfe reason thou shalt see fortune hir dutie take hir leaue thee come mee iulius caesar stood great awe hir powerp aemilius paulus aemilius great captaine sayd amongst humane thing neuer feared one amongst diuine thing alwaies stoode great feare fortune hir whome small trust placed bicause hir inconstancie mutable varietie whereby neuer vseth gratifie men liberally bestow absolute prosperitie vpon enuie mingled withall oh deceitfull fortune said demetrius thou art easily found hardly auoyded haue laboured paintingthe description fortune fained goddesse say hath swift pace loftie mind hawtie hope giue hir light wing globe vnder hir feete hir hand horne abundance full togither wrought many incredible feates armes ciuil warre grew betwixt king brother tamburlane entred brother pay obtained victory mean therupon made lieutenant general long spoiled new king weakened subdued whole kingdom persia saw himselfe captain army horsmen footme made warre baiazet emperor turkes ouercamebaiazet battel tooke prisoner obtained also great victorie souldan egypt king arabia good successe maruelled rare accompanied always vntill death much ended day amongst child peaceable gouernour innumerable country descended great sophy raigneth day greatly feared redoubted turke miserable baiazet conquered many people subdued innumerable city ended dayes iron cage wherein prisoner ouercome griefe see wife shamefully handled waiting tamburlanes table hir gowne cut downe hir nauell hir secrete partes seene vnfortunate turke beate head often agaynst cage ended lyfe neede drawe discourse shewe straunge dealinges maruellous chaunges fortune particular estate condition men seene daily amongst v seeing soueraignof foure soueraigne empire empire babylon persia graecia rome man iudgement seemed immutable inexpugnable fallen glittering shew greatnes vtter ruine subuersion last surpassed rest power remaineth onely commandement limited restrained within confines almaigne tenth part rich prouinces subiect empire cause astonished litle kingdom commonwealth ciuill gouernments end come vtmost ful point greatnes much lesse fal nature subiect change themselues desire seeke nothing else alteration assured therefore vncertaintie humane thing let v wisely prepare selues applywe must prepare selues euents euents whose cause altogither incomprehensible respect vnderstandings quite power able say haue preuented thee fortune haue stopped thy passage closed vp thy wayes entrance man putteth assurance barres locked gate yet high walles staieth himselfe vpon phylosophicall sentence discourse reason whereof capable imploy wils trauell studie thereupon neither may doubt distrust selues rather admire greatly esteeme beyng rauished affectionate spirite taketh least care morow saith epicurus commeth thereuntowho taketh greatest ioy outward good greatest ioy plutarke saith rich glory authoritie credite reioyce stande least feare contrary man seeketh ouerburning desire whereby also great feare loosing imprinted pleasure hath enioying verie weake vnstable hir husband house alongst broadest streetes citie note thereby wife ought alwaies passe greatest way found time suspected secret place whereupon suspition euill may arise come entrie hir husband house foorth hir husband house would haue report name honest woman hir garment behauiour gesture gate correspondent modestie honestie shamefastnes ware iewell hanging riben hir necke signifie bound put subiection hirthe romane bride vsed present fire water husband husband presented also hir husband water one hand fire interprete thus communication man life consisteth chiefly vse two element fire water cannot fellowship familiar neerer linked togither husband wife bicause fire water signifie communication others haue thus vnderstood fire water cleane contrary aswell first second quality man wife one hot dry nature fire cold moist nature water contrariety ioined togither make harmonie temperature loue againe would haue dissentions murmuring complaint often mariages signified therby wherin laughter without weeping rest without labor sweete without sower according nature earthly thing cannot taste honie without gall sugar without aloe many ceremony vsed ancient breuity sake also bicause smal instruction omit present therefore concludewhat signified name house discourse learne name house doth onely signifie wals roofe building ought taken familie gathered togither communicate one another necessity learne also euery mariage ought haue regard ordinance institution god politike lawes vnder liue ende trouble common tranquillitie must auoide disparitie good house age especially nature manner let v suffer selues caried away foolish passion looke chiefly vnder gratious honest behauiour may shine foorth cleare euident step vpright sincere soule void dissimulation saying wise manprou fauour deceitfull beautie vanitie woman feareth lord shall praised must also rid wedding assembly dissolutenes kind allurement voluptuousnes nicenes may rather seeme schooles honour chastitie intemperancie loosenes lay foundation mariages doubt god blesse make happie prosperous glorie name quietnes contentation v particular dutie husband towards wife chap aram phisitions stand feare feauers engendred hid cause gathered togither little little long time proceed apparant cause smal iarres daily quarrelings maried folkes vnknownesmal iarres must auoided house stranger drawing litle little incurable hardnes separate one another cause whatsoeuer therefore necessary rootes naughty sprig cut occasion eschewed might prouoke one another least lightest anger may industrie man ought aime especially called honorable estate head familie looking diligently performe dutie towards hir straightly linked vnto dissentions neuer take beginning default let v companion take occasion subiect better instructed dutie husband towards wife achitob prou reioice sayth wise man wife thy youth let hir louing hinde pleasant roe let hir breastes satisfie thee time delight hireuery man must content himselfe owne wife loue continually shouldest thou delight strange woman imbrace bosome stranger way man eye lorde pondereth pathes aser ephes husband ought loue wiues husband sayth paule loue wiues euen christ loued church gaue himselfe ought men loue wiues owne body loueth wife loueth himselfe belongeth thee amana handle v point large amana gorgias excellent orator commended cicero many place exhorted graecians long since peace concord oration woonderfull arte ended one melanthus stoode vp companie present sayd lordes behold gorgias eloquent oration exhorteth v number infinite concord yet cannot playe oratour well cause wife hir chambermaide liue quietly house wherein three ye shall daily see strife continuall dissention therefore lordes thinke great rashnes exhort v concord cannot haue himselfe priuate house truly besides vnspeakeable torment ioined riot ianglings controuersies house shamefull offence knowne stranger ancient lar houshold god heathen priuate houshold god whome called god lar may translate language god harth veneration man withdrewe himselfe harth house deadlie enimie enimie durst offer anie violence long harth vnto sanctuarie place immunitie readthemistocles saued flying harth enimie themistocles banished athens pursued would haue layed violent handes vpon fled harth deadlie enimie cause durst strike offer iniurie harth dedicated consecrated goddesse vesta placed chiefe fire house made nowe pray prohibited accounted vniust thing man quarrell iniurie offer violence euen vtter enimie beeing fled harth howe infamous acte thinke vnwoorthie nature man men iudge offer violence harth chiefly wife whowhat place wife hath next man principall person belonging bed table harth yea whole house husband called lawe companion diuine humane house daie commonly obserue offend sort come see v haue occasion quarrelling shall shewed long house haue care accounted vnciuill void discretion shall vse reason towards vnto v second selfe whome liue die let v haue regard principall point desired establishment continuance loue vpon euerie holie mariage ought first toloue first foundation euery holy mariage grounded haue already said secondly must grounded vpon conformitie agreement good honest condition lastly must hold depend prudence breedeth continuall liuely mutuall affection one towards another true testimonie whereof reuerent behauiour maxime principle granted wise men nothe best must command man woorthie meete command vnles better ouer whome commandeth therefore seemeth nature commonly giueth vigour strength authoritie grauitie prudence deedes wordes men woman effect grace cannot better shew foorth gouerning himselfethe husband must command ouer wise ouer free person reason according duty towards wife first louing hir gouerning hir gratiously free person aristotle saith perswading hir reason authoritie must offer hir iniurie either deede worde honour make much hir husband honoureth wife honoureth himselfe lawyer saith maried woman ought set foorth beames husband husband ought giue example others honour wife whereby also shall prouoke wife honour side offring hir wrong shall incense hir giue hir occasion reply vpon bitter speech end prouoke wrath behaue himselfethe fruit hard dealing one wife woorse towards wife thereby constraining hir falleth oftentimes inuent mischiefe honor thousand example heerof good author experience affoordeth many proofes reade clytemnestra wifeclytemnestra agamemnon reuenge iniurie receiued hir husband committed adulterie afterward consented death true simple reuenge woman one lighteth vpon selues sexe fraile spitefull giuen reuenge therefore men vse greater prudence gouerning managing prouerbe man bitten dog prouoking ouermuch eele oftentimesa husband must neuer beate wife lost strained ouerhard therefore let wise husband knowe must neuer deale iniuriously wife especially others must abstaine laying violent hand vpon hir ancient would haue slaues corrected rather wordes blowes much ought themarcus aurelius precept husband wife dealt withall whome god calleth helpe like v effect marcus aurelius sayd wise husband one mindeth liue peaceably wife ought aboue thing obserue rule namely admonish hir often reprehend hir seldome iupiter neuer lay hand vpon hir homer bringeth iupiter reproouing wife threatning hir rebellious neuer maketh goe farther read life ofcato cato whome giuen sworne enimie woman neuer strake wife accounting sacriledge yet knewe well howe vse place dignitie husband keepeth wife obedience aboue hath beene also bicause wife haue knowledge suspition thereof otherwise cast himselfe dangerous labyrinth king porsenna dedalus yea shall hardly haue good countenance wife time except dissemble matter may better renenged either rendring like like thinking hath iust occasion breake hir faith made hir husband seeing hath broken hir else meane vpon person suspition wife hath hir husband incontinencie husband theselues philosopher court become seruants rich thereby honoured may say much wiues whe submit themselues husbandsit honor woman obey hir husband praised become mistress ouer beseemeth ill doth yeeld subiection reape shame tha honor thereby therefore woman make choice effeminate husband delight commanding like rather guide blind follow wise clearesighted wife loue esteeme honor hir husband thinke honest dutie flow thence common contentation comfort benefit quietnes honour whole familie meane loue hir self esteem honour hir neerest lord wise woman ought thinke hir husband maners lawes hir life good wholy folow bad must patiently beare looking glasse serueth purpose although gilt anda wife compared looking glasse decked precious stone doth liuely represent face looketh woman liked albeit haue store good hir life thereafter hir behauior condition conformable hir husband looking glasse represent sadde mourning countenance one ioyful mery contrarywise smiling face sorowfull false glasse worth nothing bad wife vnreasonable frowneth hir husband desirous mery hir take honest recreation contrarywise laugheth sporteth hir selfe seeth full busines greatly troubled one token hir froward disposition despiseth affection hir husband line superficiall partes geometrician say moouenotable similitude themselues body mooue wherein wife must haue proper peculiar passion affection hir self must partaker pastime affaire thought laughter hir husband farther moone sun cleerer shineth much contrarywise hath lesse light euil wiues resembled moone obscuved commeth neerer therunto euil woman deale husband loue presence absence shall see iocund frolick may husband home sorowful pensiue moreouer wife must trust much either hir wealth nobilitie hir race hir beautie setteth neerest hir husband hart hir behauior maners conuersation taking order thatan ouerthwarting wife maketh hir selfe odious thing hard troublesom irksom hir husband euery day please agree condition troublesome conuersation wife alwais iarreth end maketh euen hir honest behauior odious hir ouergreat pinching niggardlines causeth hir sparing good huswiferie become hateful custom obserued amongst persian enimies came rushing vpon great clamor receiued silence contrarywise set vpon silence made head againsthow wife must deale hir cholerike husband ope mouth discreet wome hold peace husband cry choler contrarywise vtter word labor appease pacifie comfortable speech wise woma loueth hir husband becometh hir somtime tollerateth dissembleth euil intreatie trusting much hir co stancie vertue continuing hir dutie able bring back must gouerne hir selfea woman must disclose hir husband imperfection body discreetly neither hir neighbour hir familiar friend made acquainted sort hir complaint grieuances discouering either shal make hir self laughing stock others el giue occasion enimies hir honor prouoke sollicit hir naughtines one knowing imperfection hir husband vnder pretence seeing hir hardly delt withal perswade hir decline fro hir duty must answer example king phillip wronged graecians intreated curteously would husband vnto begin hate offer iniury perceiue woma hir acquaintance laboreth hir talke either sow increase domestical dissentio may wisely say hir self case would woman seketh make iealous desire rather see tha maliciously play ill huswife husband forsake house mariage bed whereupon may would gladly take place thus discreet woman wil giue smal eare much lesse giue place light speech fained promise disturber domestical peace neither admit nourish vain sottish opinion commonly busie mind wome ruled gouerned onely passion containing hir desire reason within couenient compasse confidence hath hir husband vertue wil breed perfect ease hir soule taking fro hir doubting occasion complaining vpo discourse giue note way whe anymaried couple must make two bed iarre displeasure falleth betweene maried folk must haue special regard make two bed mean anger indune lesser also must shun al occasion quarelling bed great bellied woman redy lie euen feeling pang hir trauell said willed hir lie vpon bed bed cure euil best time place pacifie strife man wife came vnto vpon bed quarels iniuries wrath choler bred within bed hardly appeased healed time place cotinue matter duty wife must neuer suffer enter hir husband house without expres commandement licece euery honest hir accounted honest wise humble chaste wome curiously prick vp themselues inrich body ornament ful pompe make men dissolute inclined loosenes especially make great windowworks dug giue licence eye wife ferdinando goncales hir husband prisoner daunger death went visite putting apparell abode place whilest beyng clothed hir garmentes saued himselfe zenobia queene armeniazenobia seeing hir husband hir afterward great loue hir princesse panthea loued hir husbandpanthea abradatus well died cyrus campe slue hir selfe vpon bodie artemisia queene ofartemisia caria great loue bare hir husband dead dranke ash bodie meanyng thereby sepulchre iulia wife pompey iulia sawe gowne hir husbandes bloodie wherewith offered sacrifice imagined slayne died presently porcia wifeporcia brutus heard hir husbandes death perceiued hir kinsfolkes tooke away meanes killing hir self drew hote burning cole fire threw hir mouth closed fast shee choked thereby sulpitia beyng carefully restrainedsulpitia hir mother iulia seeking hir husband lentulus sicilia whither hee banished shee went thither beyng apparelled like slaue banishing hir selfe voluntarily rather would forsake hir husbandoctauia octauia sister augustus wife antonius notwithstanding iniurie hir husband offered vnto hir preferring hir queene nothing yong faire bare great loue towards setting aside al intreatie hir brother would neuer leaue hir husband house stil brought vp child first mariage carefully hir owne moreouer sought mean reconcile two emperor saying vnworthy thing two mightie prince one euil intreatie sister bicause bewitched wicked woman warre one another vertuous prince taken hir iourney far athens ment take shipping seeke hir husband war parthian bringing hir souldiers mony furniture munition sent hir word passe farther stay rome performed sent aboue named thing seeming offended wheras mean skorned hir sporting cleopatra sight knowledge men afterward delt worse hir warre begunne augustus sent commandement octauia rome go house presently obeied albeit would therefore forsake hir husband child wept bewailed hir mishap brought hir principal cause thataria ciuill warre aria wife cecinna followed little boate vnto rome hir husband taken prisoner bicause borne armes emperour claudius condemned die would haue borne companie hir sonne lawe hir daughter stayed hir sawe strake hir head hard agaynst wall fell downe amazed beyng come hir selfe agayne sayde vnto see hinder dying cruelly ye stay mee gentle death astonished fact hir word suffered hir would ran place hir husband slewe hir selfe first spoken thus courageously vnto cecinna sorie done bicause race thy life must end seneca condemned die nero manner seneca death paulina libertie chuse kind death would caused veines opened bath wife paulina hir owne accord like hir self bath mingling togither blood greater vnion coronation long perfect loue whereof nero aduertised presently commanded hir veines stopt constraining hir thereby liue little longer continuall griefe hipparchia fairehipparchia rich woman farre loue philosopher crate hardfauoured poore maried hir kinsfolk minde followed throughout countrie poorely suffered loued better hir selfe therevpon counselled great courage asswage griefe death better stirre vp thereunto offered beare companie whereunto hir husband agreeing imbraced cast themselues deere husband pandoerus camma greekish woman countrie galatiacamma bare loue hir husband euen death reuenged great lorde called synorix put hir husband death might marrie hir gently denied first bicause thereby acquaint themselues diuers nature take pleasure thing contrary matter tinne doth soder ioine togither broken copper touching end broken piece bicause agreeth well one common friend serueth confirm preserue encrease reunite mutual friendship goodwil vpon light occasion somtimes danger breaking much fearedenmitie brother prodigious vnnaturall certain enmitie breedeth within soules thousand passion torment v especially enmitie man beareth towards brother prodigious nature body ioined togither glew bande waxe loose may reioined glewed againe naturall bodie breake rent asunder hard find soder able reunite knit well togither againe mutual friendship contractit hard matter reconcile brother fallen variance voluntarily kinne allied vnto v peraduenture fall asunder sometimes may easily vndertaken againe brother estranged fallen loue whereby nature doth necessarily linke one another hardly reconciled againe togither friendes againe yet alwayes distrust suspicion questionles impossible affaire breed time wherein liue many occasion dissention debate betweene brother namely goodshow brother must behaue themselues partition land good succession worde parting importeth bringeth diuision euery one desirous haue owne herein also must suffer matter fight themselues without adding headstrong passion couetousnesse choler hooke taketh hold seeketh set togither eares must balance consider iointly togither side right equitie declineth soone possible let remit iudgement deciding controuersies arbitrement good men yea good brother ought rather reioyce boast hath ouercome gone beyond brother gracious behauior curtesie voluntarily giuing place euery good dutie towards diuision good let v consider notable example amongst ancient great brotherly loue darius monarch persian ariamenes eldest xerxes younger great strife togither succession empire eldest alleaged birthright yonger sonne atossa daughter cyrus great borne since father crowned king next inheritour kingdome cambises dead great confederate many persian lordes diuided factious matter ariamenes came medium inariamenes armes make warre although hee greate meanes thereunto onely ordinarie traine one purposed pursue right way iustice xerxes xerxes brother comming exercised persia duty belonging king soone brother arriued willingly put kingly diademe hat went meete imbrace sent present vnto commaundement giuen bare say vnto maner xerxes thy brother honoreth thee present sentence iudgement prince lordes persia declared king thou shouldest bee second person persia ariamenes returned aunswere receyue brother giftes harte thinke kingdome persia belongeth concerning brother giue dignitie honour due vnto next selfe xerxes first nowe common consent artabanus vncle decided brought ende controuersie adiudged kingdome xerxes ariamenes presently arose seate went doe homage brother takyng right hande ledde royall kingly throne tyme forward always greatest next vnto shewed himselfe well affected towards right salamine battell sea died fighting valiauntlieantiochus seruice antiochus surnamed holie makyng warre elder brother part kingdome macedonia declared euen ambition brotherly loue quite extinguished cleane put hottest tyme warre brother seleucus lost battell great destruction men supposed haue dead bicause newes heard antiochus put purple robe clothed himselfe blacke shuttyng behauiour reuerent excellencie kinglie maiestie yet verie yoong committed act wise aduised captaine romane armie whereof strabo father captaine cinna souldiers began rebel conspire death captaine pompey discouered tooke order father safetie perceiuing souldiers trussed vp bag baggage go yeeld themselues cinna thrust himselfe middest beseeching humbly teares eies deale grosely captain end saw persisted opinion threw himselfe prostrate along ouerthwart gate campe saying vnto desirous depart horse go ouer body whereupon ashamed chaunging mindes euery one betooke againe quarter reconciled resisting boldnes wicked repressing impudencie violence punishingprou fault abhomination king saith wise man commit wickednes throne stablished iustice king sitteth throne iudgement chaseth away euill cies wise king scattereththe wicked causeth wheele turne ouer take drosse siluer prou shall proceede vessell finer take away wicked king throne shall stablished righteousnes aswell iustifieth wicked condemneth iust abhomination vnto god people nation curse suffreth euill culpable aswell committeth saith wicked thou art iust yea offence imputed asmuch suffereth done may bound stay committeth point true iustice magistrate persecute wicked drawne sword let needes forsooth abstaine seueritie keepe hand pure blood whilest sword wicked drawne commit murder violence say let doubt selues shall iudged hath giue thee kingdom power stregth glory whe heare appointed king god must withal cal mind heauely ordinace co mandeth v feat honor king wil doubt yeeld wicked tyrant honour god hath thought meet whe samuel declared people israel suffer king onely according right priuiledges maiestie tyrannical custom fashion namely would sam take sonnes daughter serue land vine garden giue seruants contrary commandement law god yet inioined obedience leauing lawful occasion resist king haue iere c saith lord ieremy made earth man beast vpon ground great power outstretched arme haue giuen vnto pleased haue giuen al land hand nebuchadnezzar king tyrant called seruant god babel seruant beast field haue also giuen serue nation shal serue sonne sonnes sonne vntil time land come also nation kingdom peruerse cruel tyrant honored reason bicause lift vp hand vnto roial maiestie bound beleeue much al king earth foolish seditious thought neuer come mindes king must handled according deserueth perfect kind life maintained soueraigne prince whatsoeuer ought inuiolable subiectes sacred sent god neither thing vsuall holy scripture prohibition kill seeke life honour onely prince also inferiour magistrate although saith scripture wicked said exodus exod thou shalt raile vpon iudges neither speake euill ruler thy people doth guiltie treason diuine humane maiestie punishment sufficient seeketh life according men lawes onely subiect guiltie high treason hath killed soueraigne prince also attempted gaue counsell consented thought yea neuer preuented taken maner point soueraigne law accounteth condemned alreadie iudgeth culpable death thought time past haue seazed vpon life prince notwithstanding repentance folowed truly gentleman normandie confessed franciscan frier minded haue killed kinga gentleman iudged die bicause thought haue killed prince francis first repented euill thought frier gaue absolution yet afterward told king thereof sent gentleman parliament paris tried common consent condemned die executed amongst u r law treason macedonian law condemned death fiue next kinsfolk conuicted conspiracie prince see straight obligation wherby bound vnto prince diuine humane right wherfore fall cruelly vexed prince voyd humanitie el polled burthened exaction one couetous prodigall despised ill defended carelesse prince yea afflicted true pietie sacrilegious vnbeleeuing soueraigne otherwise vniustly cruelly intreated first let v call mind offenceshow must behaue selues vnder tyrant committed god vndoubtedly correcteth scourge secondly let v thinke thus selues belongeth v remedie euils permitted onely call vpon god helpe whose hand hart king alteration ofpsal kingdom god dauid saith sitteth among god shal iudge whose onely looke king iudges earth shall fall confounded haue kissed sonne iesus christ haue decreed vniust lawes oppresse poore iudgement scatter lawfull right weake thatesay may praie vpon widowes poll orphan thus let people learne duetie aboue hereditarie lawfull whether king come estate right succession thucidides writeth auncient king whether kingdome giuen vertue lawe without regard daughter male descendingthe salick law excludeth daughter sonnes kingdome salicke lawe whether bee giuen meere gift kingdomes naples sicill giuen charles fraunce since giuen agayne lewes france first duke aniow whether bee left kinges thunis fez marocke vsed doe practised also henry eight king englandkingdoms left left kingdome sonne edward appointing mary hir elizabeth meanes euer prince becommeth lord estate monarchie alwayes royall lawfull like maner bee obedient lawes nature desireth subiectes bee towards leauyng euery one naturall libertie proprietie goodes looking profite commoditie commonwealth kingly gouernment aristotle compareth oeconomie although father familie gouerne house pleasure yet respecteth commoditie familie vnder happie fourme gouernement beyngof happy gouernment estate france best wee may boast wee liue fraunce goodnesse kinges neyther ordaine put thing execution mature deliberation counsaile take prince bloud notable graue persones whome call neere vnto though soueraigne power ruled moderated first king commaundeth nothing taketh effect bee signed secretary sealed great seale saye seenethe chancellor france must approoue matter passe approoued chauncellour seuere controuler matter passe kinges letter must alwayes necessitie bee approoued iudges directed examined whether obtained priuie insinuation fraudulent dealing also whether lawful vnlawfull yea criminall matter reinabling capable office dignity writ repeale banishment pardon remission skanned rigor procurer letter compelled deliuer bareheaded kneeling offer themselues prisoner estate soeuer much oftentimes men condemned executed pardon giftes expences king whether beofficers france sworne let nothing passe hurtfull realme notwithstanding king co mandement ordinarie extraordinarie chamber account examineth narowly many time cutteth haue good ground reason officer sworne let nothing passe detriment realm notwithstanding letter commandement whatsoeuer among thing king may alienate crowne reuenues without cause knowen sayd officer account parliament publike treaty neighbour state edict decree haue authoritie published high court moderation power lessened made surer durable lesse burthensome subiects wholy separated tiranny hated god men may haue knowledge discoursing thereof particularly ouer besides fiue kindes monarchy mentioned v tiranny may put sixt may call wherein monarch treading vnder foote lawes nature abuseth libertie free subiects slaues men good owne amongof tiranny name tirant auncients name tyrant honourable signified nothing else greeke worde prince gotten gouernment estate consent subiects companion made himselfe master whether wise iust prince cruel vniust deed became wicked make sure estate life good knowing fallen many men hatred bicause inuaded soueraigntie respect therfore dominion rule called tyrannical bicause gouerned lordlike maner without right ouer free men compelled forced obey generally may call tirannie prince accounteth iust law hath care either pietie iustice faith doth thing owne priuate profite reuenge pleasure good king conformeth himselfe tothe difference good king tyrant lawes god nature tyrant treadeth vnder foote one striueth enriche subiects destroy one taketh reuenge publike iniuries pardoneth owne cruelly reuengeth iniuries done himselfe forgiueth offered others one spareth honour chaste woman triumpheth shame one taketh pleasure freely admonished wisely reprooued hath done amisse misliketh nothing much graue free vertuous man one maketh great account loue people feare one neuer feare subiects standeth awe none one burtheneth little may vpon publike necessitie suppeth vp bloud gnaweth bone sucketh marrow subiectes satisfie desire one giueth estate office meete briberie oppression people selleth deare may bee careth oppression subiectes one time warre hath recourse subiects warreth none one hath garde garrison owne people none straungers one reioyceth assured rest languisheth perpetuall feare one honoured life tyme longed death defamed lyfe rent piece death example hereof diogenes girdeth dionysius euery man sight therefore diogenes sinopian meeting one day citie corinth dionysius younger tyraunt syracusa brought estate priuate man banished countrey fallen dignitie spake thus vnto truely dionysius thou art nowe estate vnwoorthie thee tyraunt standing still withall made answere like thee well diogenes bicause thou hast compassion miserable fortune replied philosopher doest thou thinke pitie thee rather grieued see slaue thou deseruest growe olde die cursed estate tyraunt thy father take thy pleasure suche safetie passe away thy tyme freely amongst v without feare say truth tirannie suche miserable condition euen practise glorie therein constrained manie tymes confesse owne mouth noof miserable condition tyrant kinde life wretched selfe tyrant dionysius hee greatest glorye estate declared much democles one familiar friendes sayd happie wilt thou quoth dionysius enjoy felicitie one day onely whereunto democles agreeddemocles quickly wearie estate dionysius hee caused serued table himselfe woont magnificence could deuised hanging meane sworde right ouer head tied roofe aloft onely one haire horse taile democles perceiued well contented make short dinner passe away rest day former estate loe quoth tyraunt vnto happie life whicha tyrant cannot long continue armed garde hangeth little threed moreouer raigne tyraunts beyng without measure reason guided onely violence cannot long continuaunce thales wise man sayde nothing straunge rare olde tyrant albeit liue miserablie perpetuall distrust euery one yea neerest kindred yet ende wretched theretyrants haue commonly euil end fewe died cruell extraordinarie death slayne murdered others persecuted straunge griefes died like mad magistrate dammages ciuill matter conscience religion iudges determine resolute sentence according opinion also called iudgement although properly may called decree cause say two principall pointes euery commonwealth magistrate must haue eies themagistrats must alwaies haue law equitie eies law equitie also execution law duty magistrate consisteth either commanding decreeing executing iudgementes called priuate publike criminallthe diuision iudgements others ciuill priuate iudgements bondage prescription gardianships wardships contract testament succession mariages publike iudgements concerne hainous offence god man sacriledge treason restitution monie bribe taken magistrats robbery king treasure forgery theft wilfull constrained murder plato speaketh large booke lawes would infinite matter smally instruction seeke diuers kind iudgements either haue beene among men well woorth noting amongest ancient grecian romanes iudgements priuat publike point point followed valerius maximus saith censor note ignominy withall disfranchised citizen rome bicause breathed yawned little loud presence estats dignity giuen vertue offred often time place iudgement necessarily force laid vpon iudges honourable profitable yea incommodious wouldan excellent way decide controuersies betweene party discord discharge themselues vprightly therein remember excellent iudgement giuen archidamus lacedemonian chosen arbitrator decide certaine contention betweene two friendes brought temple diana made sweare vpon aultar shoulde obserue precisely whatsoeuer determined wherunto yeelded iudge quoth none depart temple haue ended strife thus constrained agree among themselues archidamus freed perill loosing one friendship whome must needes haue giuen iudgement meanes put commonwealth asthe beginning euils must staied great stormes tempestes proceede exhalation vapour seene sedition ciuill warres beginne part verie light matter man woulde neuer thinke shoulde haue haue good experience france councell prince information hath beene giuen cleane contrarie truth insomuch haue felt cruell hand stranger euer would haue beleeued taken horse owne countrie therefore offering iniurie one sort liuingthe eleuenth friendly let care safetie estate watch alwaies stand vpon gard often time propound cause feare make subiects attentiue heedefull whichthe twelfth doe let contention quarrel betweene noble let others preuented yet ioined dissentions enter chiefest thing day whereunto king prince ought especially looke amongest traines nothing league parttakings nothing proceede end trouble hurt estate therefore theycontentious person must remooued court must take away occasion hatred quarrelling remooue farre court loue contention bicause quarreller themselues tarye commonwealth preseruation euery good commonwealth vnder fiue thing namely let loued faithfully defended manfully adorned nobilitie ordred profitably gouerned prudently naturally ingrafted euery liuing creature loue place tooke beginning sauage beastes saith cassiodorus loue wood forest bird loue ayre fish sea andall liuing creature loue place birth riuers men loue originall place birth worde men beastes loue place purpose liue continue long loue saith aristotle priuate profite publike wealth looseth name good citizen taketh vnto name wicked subiect therfore euery one great small ought dedicate good gift benefit country louing fellowsubiects exercising charge calling faithfully dutie also manfully defend commonwealth forraine incursion defendeth countrey defendeth himselfe refuseth die cicero saith defence countrey dieth togither ouerthrowenit dutie euery subiect defend countrey inhabitant therewithall destroyed man therefore ought feare daunger defence countrey better die many many die said iustinian emperour defence commonwealth liue alwaies glorie therefore euery one ought arme himselfe manhood one kind heroicall fortitude morall philosopher say may seruiceable safegard time warre must alwayes haue armour readie couenient force helpe friend resist enimies containe disobedient subiectes within compasse nowe hauing hitherto intreated policie chiefly respecteth tyme peace must hereafter companion referre discourse small knowledge haue warlike discipline first thinke must oppose time peace warre one agaynst consider cleane contrary effectes may bee much easily ledde perswaded desire procure best profitable euery estate monarchie therefore propounde vnto matter discourse vpon achitob rom col possible much saith apostle haue peace men let peace god rule harte ye called one body truely without peace rich pouertie mirth mourning life death man perfectly know benefit peace hath triall burthen warre aser leuit ye walke ordinaunces saith eternall god send peace land ye obey despise mine ordinaunces send sword vpon shall auenge quarell couenaunt ye shall deliuered hand enimie let v heare amana discourse vpon propounded vnto v amana lycurgus entring gouernement lacedemonians finding estate greatly corrupted determined himselfe change whole policie thought onely make particular lawes ordinance would doe good slender medicine would profit corrupt bodie full many disease order taken purging resoluing consuming euill humor new forme rule life might afterward prescribed enterprise although great difficult yet fell well lawes receiued approoued armes certaine right warre shall alwaies continue amongst men bring subiection conquerours person good whome ouercome seemeth also thought neuer true peace amongst men onely name prince people liue continuall distrust one another doe nothing else part watch surprize plutark elegantly setteth notwithstanding league goodly agreement passe betweene numa numa referred lawes peace pompilius second fountaine goodnes honestie many riuers issued water italy peaceable prudence communicated hande hande vnto whole worlde nowe although two men haue beene greatly praised commended sundrie rare vertues yet men approoue extremity followed forme gouernment pernitions mooueth continueth warre onely subdue neighbour inlarge border countrie vsurpethe discommodities long peace men right sauoureth brutishnes humanitie long peace bringeth many discommodities making men insolent commonly great prosperitie also nice lauish effeminate abundance wealth idlenes therefore plato aristotle polybius reprooue lycurgus bicause propounded onely exercise vertue warre citizen least foure necessarie establishment preseruation euery empire saying lawes wel ordained make men valiant iust temperat prudent maintained although reason varietie change humane affaire cannot continue long adorned worlde yet abide many yeeres moreouer element bred one another alter fro going returning continually first matter receiueth selfe cause cannot seene simple mixed wherupon ariseth teperature al thing wither drougth burne heate neither ouerwhelmed great moisture grow stiff excessiue cold vertues whereby city another vigor dignitie iustice without temperance rigour fortitude separated iustice rashnes crueltie without prudence iustice craft suttletie conclude temperance without fortitude ought rather called cowardlines nicenes whereby see interlaced depend sort one another cannot separated fal otherwise estate wherein disorder taketh place must necessitie vtterly ouerthrowne changed learned philosophicall discourse draw good lesson namely euery estate wel instituted continuance temperature foure vertues must necessarily kept men may instructed howe gouerne themselues well time peace warre obserue moderation therein knowing deale time may ready fit warre necessity vrgeth hauing thispeace preferred warre end attaine peace must alwaies preferred rest trauell good euill shal easily vnderstand considering contrary effect certaine philosophie best exercisedthe effect peace time peace trouble war spirite quiet fit euery honest kind rest art science go well forward lawes force iustice flourisheth vertue sheweth hir effect better vice languisheth zeale pietie encreaseth discipline church authorised noble meane man preserueth augmenteth wealth trade trafficke free briefly euery one receiueth good commoditiethe effect warre consequently whole bodie commonwealth looke effect time warre commonly bringeth foorth desire hauing awakened couetousnes encreaseth iustice falleth ground force violence beareth sway spoiling raigneth riot set libertie wicked men authoritie good men oppressed innocencie troden vnder foote maiden wiues defloured country wasted house burnt church destroied tomb broken downe good spoiled murder committed vertue banished among men vice honoured lawes contemned broken seruice god forsaken estate church derided nobilitie people burdened infinite charge costes kinde trade hindered briefly calamitie miserie aboundeth commonwealth time warre maywhat kingdom happie iudge kingdome happie wherein prince obedient lawe god nature magistrate prince life war maketh menwarre maketh men cruell peace gentle barbarous mutinous cruell peace maketh curteous tractable read englishman time past seditious vntameable onely prince could would also english merchant necessity lodged apart selues towne antwarpe constrained one house common merchant stranger except englishman house themselues bicause could abide ioined others chiefe cause strang qualitie bicause countrie bordered vpon two estate nation enimies namely vpon frenchman scot whome continuall warre since concluded peace ioined league france scotland became mild ciuill contrariwise frenchman inferiour nation whatsoeuer curtesie humanitie greatly changed naturall disposition become sauage since ciuill warres began like plutarke saith happened inhabitant sicilia meanes continuall warre grew like brute beastes archidamus king lacedemonia knowing well effect peace warre heere briefly touched v hearing elians sent succor archadians toarchidamus letter elians warre tooke occasion write vnto laconicall manner steede long discourse archidamus elians peace goodly thing another time gaue notable testimonie farre preferred peace warre made answer one commended bicause hee obtained battell foresaid archadians beene better ouercome prudence rather force selfe reason louing peace abhorringcato misliked caesar breaking peace breaker thereof cause cato full senate opposed himselfe request caesar friendes made people offer sacrifice way thanksgiuing god notable victory gotten germanes surprized discomfited said cato rather opinion deliuered hand whome hath wronged without cause violating peace people rome may punish thinke good ende whole fault breaking faith promise may cast vpon alone laid vpon citie cause thereof say truth wise men greatly feare beginning warre end growne ripenes men wanting experience worldly affaire haue rashly vnskilfully sowne seede thereof hardly greatest wisest king plucke vp againe without great labour perill therefore desirous hastie begin warre peruert order reason bicause beginne execution force ought last due consultation deserueth greater honour praise procureth peace winneth enimies hart loue obtaineth victorie shedding blood cruelly thiswherefore must begin warre onely reason saith cicero must begin warre may liue peace receiue wrong must done haue required satisfaction iniurie offered consideration phocion great athenian captaine laboured stoppe warre people athens determined make macedonian perswasion leosthenes phocion disswaded athenian warre demanded would counsell athenian make warre see quoth yong men fully resolued leaue rankes rich men contribute monie willingly oratours abstaine robbing commonwealth neuertheles armie leauied counsell many woondering greatnes beautie thereof asked howe liked preparation faire one brunt said phocion feare returne continuance warre bicause see citie hath meanes get monie vessel men warre beside foresight approoued euent although leosthenes prospered beginning enterprise whereupon phocion demanded whether woulde gladly haue doone great excellent thing answered would haue omitted counsell gaue yet end slaine voyage grecian armie ouerthrowne antipater craterus two macedonian citie athens brought extremitie constrained sende blanke capitulation peace receiue within garrison stranger thus falleth commonly seeke war meanes either right wrong euerie princethe fruit vniust warre desireth manner stirreth vppe himselfe hatred weapon neighbour vexeth greeueth subiects vnwoorthily seeking rather rule ouer violence gaine good iustice quite ouerthroweth countrie preferring dominion greatnes owne glorie benefite quietnes safetie thereof oftentimes diminisheth owne authoritie brought subiection enimies whilst laboreth possesse another man right force augustus emperour warre lawfull said haue good lawfull warre must commended god iustified philosopherstraian neuer vndertooke vniust warre aelius spartianus affirmeth traian romane emperor neuer ouercome battell bicause vndertooke war except cause therof iust may say warre betweene christian iustified still remainethantigonus testimonie iniustice warre cause scruple testimonie antigonus elder wherein accuseth himselfe notable shewe great wickednes iniustice warre vsed speech philosopher offered dedicated vnto treatise made iustice thou art foole friend come tel iustice thou caesar seest beate downe men townes caesar answered little lesse metellus tribune people desirous keepe taking monie common treasurie alleadged vnto lawes forbad whome monarch replied time offamine plague nothing heape euils misery easily draweth allureth violence euill disposition many followe themalcontents glad war state time desire change glad occasion ground platformes vpon could doe time peace
